content.question:
The following information is for an aircraft in the cruise at 11:50 UTC.
Cruise level: FL410
OAT: ISA +10°C
Mach No: 0.86
Wind component: -25 kt
What will be the Groundspeed?

key_points: TAS = Mach No × 38
95 √ OAT (Kelvin) ISA temp
learning.explanation: TAS = Mach No × 38.95 √ OAT (Kelvin) ISA temp. FL410, 15 - 2 x 41 = - 67 ºC. As the ISA temperature goes only to - 56.5º C, we will consider - 56.5º + 10º = - 46.5º Finally convert to Kelvin, 273º - 46.5º = 226.5º K TAS = 0.86 x 38.95 √ 226.5 = 504 kts A negative wind component means that component is slowing the flight path of the aircraft over the ground, G/S = 504 - 25 = 479 kts.

content.question:
Using Mental Dead Reckoning (MDR), determine the ground speed, given:
Track: 136°(T)
TAS: 465 kt
Wind velocity: 196°(T)/50 kt

key_points: Mental Dead Reckoning (MDR) headwind/tailwind component The H/TWC can be estimated using the values from the following table: 90º - Wind angle 10º 20º 30º 40º 50º 60º % of wind speed 0
learning.explanation: Mental Dead Reckoning (MDR) headwind/tailwind component The H/TWC can be estimated using the values from the following table: 90º - Wind angle 10º 20º 30º 40º 50º 60º % of wind speed 0.2 0.3 0.5 0.6 0.8 0.9 Wind Angle is the difference between the wind direction and the track: 196º - 136º = 60º The wind is 60º from the right of the track, therefore the aircraft is experiencing a Headwind Component (HCW). Wing Angle (WA): 60º 90º - WA = 30º Wind Speed: 50 kt HWC = (0.5) x 50 = 25 kt Ground Speed = True Airspeed - Headwind Component (HWC) = 465 kt - 25 kt = 440 kt

content.question: An aircraft following a standard instrument departure procedure, which requires a minimum climb gradient of 6%, climbs with an average TAS of 190 kt and experiences a headwind component of 15 kt. What is the minimum vertical speed (ft/min) required to comply with the minimum climb gradient requirements?

key_points: Climb Gradient is the ratio of the height gained for a given horizontal distance, in the same units of measurement, expressed as a percentage
Rate of Climb is the aircraft's vertical speed, the height gained per unit of time, usually expressed in feet per minute
Considering an aircraft in a steady climb, the minimum vertical speed in ft/min is given by the formula: Rate of Climb = Climb Gradient(%) x GS x 6080 / 6000
learning.explanation: Climb Gradient is the ratio of the height gained for a given horizontal distance, in the same units of measurement, expressed as a percentage. Rate of Climb is the aircraft's vertical speed, the height gained per unit of time, usually expressed in feet per minute. Considering an aircraft in a steady climb, the minimum vertical speed in ft/min is given by the formula: Rate of Climb = Climb Gradient(%) x GS x 6080 / 6000. Thus, for a climb gradient of 6% and a Groundspeed of: TAS - headwind component = 190 kt - 15 kt = 175 kt, the Rate of Climb will be: Rate of Climb (ft/min) = 6 % x 175 kt x 6080 / 6000 = 1 064 ft/min, which is very close to 1 100 ft/min.

content.question: The pilot of an aircraft changes its heading to the right, from 214º to 334º and makes a rate-1 turn. The duration of this manoeuvre is:

options.A: impossible to calculate, because we need the aircraft's TAS.
options.D: impossible to calculate, because we need the aircraft's angle of bank.

key_points: If the turn is unbalanced, an aircraft either slips into, or skids out of the turn, thereby reducing the aerodynamic efficiency of the aircraft

To help correct for these unwanted conditions, the aircraft is flown using the balance part of the turn and balance indicator During a balanced turn the ball remains in the centre of the balance indicator and the pilot remains upright in the seat relative to the aircraft, with no tendency to lean
Rate of turn is the measurement of how long it takes for an aircraft to turn, measured in degrees per second
learning.explanation: If the turn is unbalanced, an aircraft either slips into, or skids out of the turn, thereby reducing the aerodynamic efficiency of the aircraft. To help correct for these unwanted conditions, the aircraft is flown using the balance part of the turn and balance indicator During a balanced turn the ball remains in the centre of the balance indicator and the pilot remains upright in the seat relative to the aircraft, with no tendency to lean. Rate of turn is the measurement of how long it takes for an aircraft to turn, measured in degrees per second. This is particularly important during instrument flying where rate-1 turns are usually carried out at a rate of 3° per second. This means that the aircraft turns through 180° in 1 minute, or 360° in 2 minutes. A steeper angle of bank is required to carry out a rate-1 turn at higher airspeeds. To solve this exercise, first we need to calculate how many degrees was the turn performed and then apply the rate of turn: 334º - 214º = 120º at 3º/second (rate-1 turn) 120/3º = 40 seconds Note: This question is out of the scope of GNAV, however a student has confirmed that it appeared in their General Navigation exam.

content.question: What is the density altitude, given a pressure altitude of FL55 and a static air temperature of +33°C?

key_points: Note: This should not be a GNAV question
Density altitude is not particularly important to GNAV specifically, and calculating it is not part of the GNAV learning objectives, so you should appeal this question if you see it in a GNAV exam
Feedback from one authority shows that has been seen in this exam
learning.explanation: Note: This should not be a GNAV question. Density altitude is not particularly important to GNAV specifically, and calculating it is not part of the GNAV learning objectives, so you should appeal this question if you see it in a GNAV exam. Feedback from one authority shows that has been seen in this exam. Density altitude is a measure of the environmental air density, in comparison to where you would find that same density in the International Standard Atmosphere (ISA), so you end up with an altitude measurement. A high density altitude means low air density, and a low density altitude means high air density (what you would get at low-level). Density altitude can be calculated in 2 main ways, by flight computer or by mathematical calculation. By flight computer (CRP-5) it is relatively simple, in the "AIR SPEED" window, line up the pressure altitude with the OAT, and read off the density altitude in the "DENSITY ALTITUDE" window (x1000 ft). In this case, you get just under 9000 ft, but this is not the most accurate measurement in the world. We could show a picture in the annex, but flight computers are each very slightly different, so different answers could easily be found on different computers. By mathematical calculation, you take the pressure altitude, and adjust it for temperature by 120 ft per °C different from ISA. As high temperature is lower density, this means that higher than ISA temperature means a higher density altitude, and lower than ISA temperature means a lower density altitude. ISA temperature at 5500 ft (FL55) is 15 - 2(5.5) = 4°C, so with an OAT of +33°C, we are at ISA +29°C, meaning our density altitude is higher than our pressure altitude. The difference is 120 ft/°C x 29°C = 3480 ft, so the Density altitude is 5500 + 3480 = 8980 ft, closest answer 9000 ft

content.question: What is the relationship between air distance and ground distance with a headwind?

options.A: Ground distance and air distance are independent of wind.
options.B: Air distance is greater than ground distance.
options.C: Ground distance is greater than air distance.
options.D: Air distance and ground distance are equal.

key_points: The air distance is the distance flown in a given time at a given TAS
TAS is the aircraft’s speed through the atmosphere
The ground distance is the distance covered over the Earth’s surface
learning.explanation: The air distance is the distance flown in a given time at a given TAS. TAS is the aircraft’s speed through the atmosphere. The ground distance is the distance covered over the Earth’s surface. Ground speed is the aircraft’s speed over the Earth’s surface, i.e. the resulting speed that the aircraft travels across the Earth’s surface when wind is applied to the TAS. The ground speed is calculated by subtracting a headwind component or adding a tailwind component from TAS: Ground speed = TAS + tailwind component or Ground speed = TAS - headwind component Therefore, with a headwind, air distance is greater than ground distance.

content.question:
Using trigonometry, calculate the tailwind component for the following information given:
Runway 33
Surface wind (from the tower): 190°/15 kt,
Variation: 20°W

key_points: When resolving the wind into head/tailwind and crosswind components, the mathematically correct way to do this, is to apply trigonometry
For this question: The Crosswind component (XWC) is: Wind speed x Sin of the Angle difference between Rwy and Wind direction = 15 kt x Sin (330° - 190°) = 10 kt rounded
The Tailwind component (TWC) is: Wind speed x Cos of the Angle difference between Rwy and Wind direction = 15 kt x Cos (330° - 190°) = 12 kt approx
learning.explanation: When resolving the wind into head/tailwind and crosswind components, the mathematically correct way to do this, is to apply trigonometry. For this question: The Crosswind component (XWC) is: Wind speed x Sin of the Angle difference between Rwy and Wind direction = 15 kt x Sin (330° - 190°) = 10 kt rounded. The Tailwind component (TWC) is: Wind speed x Cos of the Angle difference between Rwy and Wind direction = 15 kt x Cos (330° - 190°) = 12 kt approx. NOTES: Both wind and runway directions are magnetic, thus you don't have to apply any variation. Any written meteorological information (TAF, METAR, SIGMET, etc) will be given in true direction. Any wind direction given by the ATC is magnetic and the runway is also a magnetic direction. So, no need to apply the variation given.

content.question:
An aircraft at FL120, IAS 200 kt, OAT -5°C and wind component +30 kt, is required to reduce speed in order to cross a reporting point 5 MIN later than planned.
Assuming flight conditions do not change, when 100 NM from the reporting point IAS should be reduced to...

key_points: To be possible add a wind vector given in knots, first a conversion from IAS to TAS must be carried in order to obtain the G/S
CAS/IAS to TAS with your flight computer Set pressure altitude in the window opposite the OAT in Celsius
Without moving the computer’s scales, read TAS on the outer scale opposite to CAS
learning.explanation: To be possible add a wind vector given in knots, first a conversion from IAS to TAS must be carried in order to obtain the G/S. CAS/IAS to TAS with your flight computer Set pressure altitude in the window opposite the OAT in Celsius. Without moving the computer’s scales, read TAS on the outer scale opposite to CAS. Set PA 12 000 against -5ºC, opposite to IAS 200 kts read TAS 242 kts. With the actual TAS of 242 kts and with 30 kts tailwind, the aircraft would cross the reporting point after: FT = 100 / (242 + 30) = 0º22’ The aircraft is requested to cross the reporting point 5’ later than planned, which makes a FT of 0º27’. New G/S = 100 / 0º27’ = 222 kts New TAS = G/S - Tailwind component = 222 -30 = 192 kts With the conversion side of the flight computer, set PA 12 000 against -5ºC, opposite to TAS 192 kts read IAS 159 kts.

content.question:
What wind vector shall be used for calculating the average GS for a descent from FL200 to the Initial Approach Fix (IAF) at a pressure altitude of 4000 ft?
Surface wind: 220º/15 kt
W/V at FL50: 240º/25 kt
W/V at FL100: 250º/35 kt
W/V at FL150: 250º/45 kt
W/V at FL200: 260º/35 kt
W/V at FL240: 300º/125 kt

key_points: Learning Objective 061
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 061.01.08.02.02: WV used for descent problems is the WV at the altitude 1/2 of the descent altitude. The height lost in ths descent is 20 000 - 4 000 = 16 000 ft. Half of this descent is therefore 8 000 ft, and this point occurs when passing 8 000 + 4 000 = 12 000 ft. Therefore, the average wind we should use for calculations in the descent is the wind at FL120. For this, we must interpolate 2/5 of the way from FL100 to FL150. The wind direction at FL100 and FL150 is the same, 250º, so does not need to be interpolated. The wind speed at FL100 is 35 kt, and at FL150 it is 45 kt; a difference of 10 kt. 2/5ths of this difference is 4 kt up from 35 kt, so 39 kt. Therefore, the wind we should use is 250º/39 kt.

content.question: An aircraft is cruising at FL410, Mach 0.86. The ISA deviation is -12ºC. What is the TAS of the aircraft?

key_points: Mach number can be calculated using the following formula: M = TAS / LSS Where M stands Mach number and LSS is local speed of sound
The Local Speed of Sound is only dependent on absolute temperature and can be calculated as follows: LSS = 38
95 x √ K T(K) = ºC + 273 (1) Determine the OAT at FL410: ISA temperature at FL410 = -56
learning.explanation: Mach number can be calculated using the following formula: M = TAS / LSS Where M stands Mach number and LSS is local speed of sound. The Local Speed of Sound is only dependent on absolute temperature and can be calculated as follows: LSS = 38.95 x √ K T(K) = ºC + 273 (1) Determine the OAT at FL410: ISA temperature at FL410 = -56.5ºC ISA dev = -12ºC Thus, OAT = - 56.5 - 12 = -68.5ºC (1) Convert ºC into K: K = -68.5ºC + 273 = 204.5 K (2) Calculate LSS: LSS = 38.95 x √204.5 = 557 kt (3) Determine the Mach number: TAS = ? kt LSS = 557 kt M = 0.86 0.86 = TAS / 557 kt = 479 kt Note: In an International Standard Atmosphere (ISA) atmosphere, the temperature declines by 2°C for every 1 000 ft of ascent until reaching the Tropopause, which occurs at an altitude of 36,000 feet. Beyond this point, the temperature is considered constant and remains at -56.5°C.

Given the following information, calculate the drift and Wind Correction Angle WCA:
Aircraft True Airspeed TAS: 170 kt
Course: 200° T
Wind Velocity W/V (T): 270°/30 kt

key_points: Determining Heading and G/S with the flight computer: (1) Place the centre of the rotating disk on the value representing the true airspeed (170 kt)

learning.explanation: Determining Heading and G/S with the flight computer: (1) Place the centre of the rotating disk on the value representing the true airspeed (170 kt). (2) Place wind direction (270º) under the true index. (3) Mark wind velocity (30 kt) upwards from centre. NOTE: When the question provides a track => mark wind velocity upwards from centre. When the heading is known => mark wind velocity downwards from centre. (4) Place your true track (200º) under the true index. WCA 10ºR corresponds to a drift of 10ºL. Drift is the angular difference between the track of the aircraft across its heading. Wind Correction Angle is the angular value opposite to the drift angle, and it refers to the heading angle correction in order to keep your aircraft in the desired track.

content.question:
The True course in the flight log is 270°, the forecast wind is 045°T/15 kt and the TAS is 150 kt. After 15 minutes of flying with the planned TAS and TH the aircraft is 2 NM north of the intended track and 2.5 NM ahead of the dead reckoning position.
The track angle error TKE is..

key_points: Solving from Heading (HDG), knowing WV, TAS and required track
Set wind direction to 045º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top
Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 150 kt
learning.explanation: Solving from Heading (HDG), knowing WV, TAS and required track. Set wind direction to 045º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 150 kt. Mark the wind velocity 15 kt down from the centre point. Initially, set the True Track to 270º under the "TRUE HEADING" index. Note that this heading would result in 4ºL drift and a track of 266º. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading minus the drift gives a track of 270º. This occurs at a heading of 274º with 4ºL drift. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 160 kt. It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning. If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track. The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good. The difference between them is called track error (TE). The angle at which we want to close to come back to the planned track is the closing angle (CA). The CA will depend how much further we want to rejoin the planned track. The 1 in 60 rule can be used to calculate the TE and the CA. TE = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 GS = 160 kts Planned track distance flown = 160 x 15’ = 40 NM => This distance is based on the forecast wind, but the exercise states that the aircraft is 2.5 ahead of the dead reckoning position, actual position = 40 + 2.5 = 42.5 NM. TE = (2/42.5) x 60 = approx. 3º

content.question: An aircraft with a constant TAS of 180 kt, initially follows a magnetic track of 250°M, because of a drift 8°L. After turning, it follows a magnetic track of 340°M, because of a drift 8°R. What is the wind velocity and direction (T°), if magnetic variation is 10° East?

key_points: Radial is a magnetic bearing extending from a VOR/VORTAC/TACAN
Drift is the angle difference from the aircraft’s heading to its actual track (track made good)
When following a magnetic track of 250°M, its true track is: 250°M + 10°E = 260°T (Variation East - Magnetic Least)
learning.explanation: Radial is a magnetic bearing extending from a VOR/VORTAC/TACAN. Drift is the angle difference from the aircraft’s heading to its actual track (track made good). When following a magnetic track of 250°M, its true track is: 250°M + 10°E = 260°T (Variation East - Magnetic Least). And since it drifts by 8° Left, its heading is: 260°T + 8° = 268°T. When following a magnetic track of 340°M, its true track is: 340°M + 10°E = 350°T (Variation East - Magnetic Least). And since it drifts by 8° Right, its heading is: 350°T - 8° = 342°T. A method to assess the wind is to use the drift on different headings, known as multi-drift wind method: Place the centre dot over TAS 180 kt and put true heading 268°T under the True Index. Draw a line down the 8° left drift. Now put the next heading 342°T under the True Index and draw a line down the 8° right drift again. The point where the two drift lines intersect is the end of the wind vector. Rotate the disc until the intersection of the two drift lines is immediately under the centre dot on the 0° drift line. Read off the wind direction below the True Index as 305°T. And the wind speed is the difference between the value under the centre dot (180) and the value under the drift lines intersection (144): 180 kt - 144 kt = 36 kt. Thus, the wind velocity and direction (T°) is 305°/ 36 kt.

key_points: The heights on the glideslope can be calculted using the formula: Height difference (ft) = Glidepath Angle(o) x Distance to go (ft) / 60
So, solving for Distance to go, we get: Distance to go (ft) = (Height difference (ft) x 60) / Glidepath angle (o)
The aircraft descends from cruise altitude 5 500 ft to the traffic pattern altitude 2 000 ft, thus the height difference is 3 500 ft
learning.explanation: The heights on the glideslope can be calculted using the formula: Height difference (ft) = Glidepath Angle(o) x Distance to go (ft) / 60. So, solving for Distance to go, we get: Distance to go (ft) = (Height difference (ft) x 60) / Glidepath angle (o). The aircraft descends from cruise altitude 5 500 ft to the traffic pattern altitude 2 000 ft, thus the height difference is 3 500 ft. Therefore, the horizontal distance covered during the descent is: Distance to go (ft) = (3 500 ft x 60) / 3° = 70 000 ft or 70 000 ft / 6 080 = 11.51 NM, rounded 12 NM. The aircraft's average Rate of Descent is 750 ft/min, which means that it loses 750 ft in 1 min. Therefore, the aircraft loses 3 500 ft in: 3 500 ft / 750 ft/min = 4.67 minutes or 4 minutes 40 seconds. Finally, the aircraft to reach downwind from cruise altitude 5 500 ft to the traffic pattern altitude 2 000 ft following a 3° glidepath angle, the descent must be initiated at 12 NM prior to downwind, and with a Rate of Descent of 750 ft/min, it will last for 4 minutes 40 seconds.

key_points: Deviation is called the difference between the direction of magnetic north and that of compass north

learning.explanation: Deviation is called the difference between the direction of magnetic north and that of compass north. The deviation experienced is specific to each aircraft and varies with heading and magnetic latitude. The variation with heading occurs because sometimes the resultant aircraft fields will oppose the Earth's field and sometimes reinforce them. Which heading this occurs on, depends on how the deviating fields are aligned within the aircraft. The variation with magnetic latitude occurs because the horizontal component of the Earth's magnetic field varies in strength depending where it is detected. At the magnetic equator, all the field is in the horizontal component, at the poles the horizontal component is weak to non-existent. Where the horizontal component is weak, the deviating forces are proportionally stronger and therefore the amount of deviation is greater near the poles and correspondingly less at the magnetic equator.

content.question: The distance between geodetic parallels of latitude on the surface of the WGS 84 ellipsoid…

key_points: The Earth is roughly spherical
Because of its spin it is slightly fatter at the equator and slightly flattened at the poles, a shape known as an oblate spheroid or an ellipsoid
You might come across the term "Geoid"
learning.explanation: The Earth is roughly spherical. Because of its spin it is slightly fatter at the equator and slightly flattened at the poles, a shape known as an oblate spheroid or an ellipsoid. You might come across the term "Geoid". In geodesy, a reference ellipsoid is a mathematically defined surface that approximates the geoid. Because of their relative simplicity, reference ellipsoids are used as a preferred surface on which geodetic network computations are performed and point coordinates such as latitude, longitude and elevation are defined. Modern navigation systems, like GPS, ude these reference systems and the most common of these is the World Geodetic System of 1984 or WGS 84, created by the United States military. Geodetic latitude and longitude is used to define a position on the WGS 84 ellipsoid for aviation charts. Geodetic latitude is the angle that a line drawn perpendicular to the surface through a point on a spheroid makes with the equatorial plane (plumb-line on the ellipsoid) and is other than the geocentric (earth centred) latitude. Despite the fact that, in general navigation, we assume that one degree of latitude along a meridian equals to 60 nm. In fact, using a WGS84 ellipsoid, one degree of latitude has a length of 59.7 nm (110.574 km) at the equator and increases progressively with increasing latitude up to 60.3 nm (111.694 km) at the poles.

learning.explanation: The distance flown in 3 min (Distance 1) is: Distance 1 = GS / Time = (90 kt + 30 kt) x 3/60 hr = 6 NM. We know that the Relative bearing at first position is 45˚ to the left. Therefore, the angle at the airplane's location at old position equals to 45˚. After three minutes, the Relative bearing is 90˚ to the left. Therefore, after three minutes, the angle in the triangle at airplane location equals to 90˚. The difference in bearings is 45˚. Therefore, the triangle angle at landmark location is also 45˚. As we have triangle with two equal angles of 45˚, it is an isosceles triangle. Therefore, distance flown in 3 minutes (6 NM) equals to the distance from the airplane's new location to the landmark = 6 NM.

First a conversion from a mach no

M = TAS / LSS LSS = 38.95 √K LSS = 38.95 √273 - 44 = 589.42 TAS = M x LSS = 0.86 x 589.42 = 507 kts GS = TAS – Headwind = 507 – 110 kt = 397 kt Second Step: Calculate flight time 420 NM / 397 kt = 1 h 04 min to cross the reporting point => The A/C is requested to cross the reporting point 5’ later than planned, which makes a FT of 1h 9 min. Third Step: Calculate the TAS in order to cross 5 min later. 420 NM / 1h 9 min = 365 kt (GS) TAS = GS + Headwind TAS = 365 + 110 = 475 kt Forth Step: Calculate Mach no for TAS 475 M = 475 / 589.42 = 0.81

content.question: The distance in NM between the point G (51°00'N, 004°00'E) and point H (51°00'N, 002°00'W) is ...

key_points: The two points lie on the same parallel of latitude
So, the distance between them is given by the formula: Departure (NM) = Change of Longitude (minutes) x Cosine of Latitude
The points are in different hemispheres
learning.explanation: The two points lie on the same parallel of latitude. So, the distance between them is given by the formula: Departure (NM) = Change of Longitude (minutes) x Cosine of Latitude. The points are in different hemispheres. So, to get the Change of Longitude, add their longitudes: 004°00'+ 002°00' = 6°. Thus, the distance between the two points is: Departure (NM) = Change of Longitude (minutes) x Cosine of Latitude = 6° x 60' x Cos (51°) = 226.6 NM.

content.question: An aircraft departs from point A (48°12’ N, 004°52’ E) and flies 416 NM south to point B. From point B, aircraft flies 200 NM east to point C. What are the coordinates of point C?

key_points: The aircraft initially flies South, i
e
180° along a meridian, for 416 NM to point B
learning.explanation: The aircraft initially flies South, i.e. 180° along a meridian, for 416 NM to point B. It is known that "1' change of latitude along a meridian or the Equator equals to 1 NM". So, 416 NM along a meridian correspond to: 416' or 6° 56' change of latitude. Since the aircraft flies South, the latitude will decrease and the latitude at point B will be: 48°12’ N - 6° 56' = 41°16’ N. Thus, the coordinates at point B will be: 41°16’ N 004°52’ E. After point B, the aircraft continues East, i.e. 090° along a parallel of latitude, for 200 NM to point C. The distance along a parallel of latitude is given by the formula: Departure (NM) = Change of Longitude(') x Cosine of Latitude. Solving for Change of Longitude('), we get: Change of Longitude(') = Departure (NM) / Cosine of Latitude = 200 NM / Cos 41,27° = 266' or 4.43° or 4° 26'. Since the aircraft flies East, the longitude will increase and the longitude at point C will be: 004°52’E + 4° 26' = 009°18’ N. Thus, the coordinates at point C will be: 41°16’ N 009°18’ E.

content.question: Which statement about meridians is correct?

options.A: The plane of a meridian is parallel to the Equator.
options.B: All meridians are parallel to the Greenwich Meridian.
options.C: A meridian and its anti-meridian form a complete great circle.
options.D: A meridian is a complete great circle of 360°.

key_points: A great circle is the largest possible circle that can be drawn around a sphere
All spheres have great circles
If you cut a sphere at one of its great circles, you'd cut it exactly in half
learning.explanation: A great circle is the largest possible circle that can be drawn around a sphere. All spheres have great circles. If you cut a sphere at one of its great circles, you'd cut it exactly in half. A great circle has the same circumference, or outer boundary, and the same centre point as its sphere. The geometry of spheres is useful for mapping the Earth and other planets. The Earth is not a perfect sphere, but it maintains the general shape. All the meridians on Earth are parts great circles. Meridian and its anti meridian for a great circle. Meridians, including the prime meridian, are the north-south lines we use to help describe exactly where we are on the Earth. All these lines of longitude meet at the poles, cutting the Earth neatly in half. The Equator is another of the Earth's great circles. If you were to cut into the Earth right on its Equator, you'd have two equal halves: the Northern and Southern Hemispheres. The Equator is the only east-west line that is a great circle. All other parallels (lines of latitude) get smaller as you get near the poles. Great circles can be found on spheres as big as planets and as small as oranges. If you cut an orange exactly in half, the line you cut is the orange's great circle. And until you eat one or both halves, you have two equal hemispheres of the same orange. Great circles are also useful in planning routes. The shortest path between two points on the surface of a sphere is always a segment of a great circle. Plotting great circles comes in very handy for airplane pilots trying to fly the shortest distance between two points.

The angle at which we want to close to come back to the planned track is the closing angle (CA). The CA will depend how much further we want to rejoin the planned track. In order to determine the TKE the directions must have the same reference. content.question: An aircraft following an approach procedure, which requires an approximate descent gradient of 6.6%, descends with an average groundspeed of 185 kt. What is the corresponding vertical speed (ft/min) required during the descent?

key_points: Descent Gradient is the ratio of the loss of height for a given horizontal distance, in the same units of measurement, expressed as a percentage
Rate of Descent is the aircraft's vertical speed, the loss of height per unit of time, usually expressed in feet per minute
Considering an aircraft in a steady descent, the vertical speed in ft/min is given by the formula: Rate of Descent = Descent Gradient(%) x GS x 6080 / 6000
learning.explanation: Descent Gradient is the ratio of the loss of height for a given horizontal distance, in the same units of measurement, expressed as a percentage. Rate of Descent is the aircraft's vertical speed, the loss of height per unit of time, usually expressed in feet per minute. Considering an aircraft in a steady descent, the vertical speed in ft/min is given by the formula: Rate of Descent = Descent Gradient(%) x GS x 6080 / 6000. Thus, for a descent gradient of 6.6% and a Groundspeed of 185 kt, the Rate of Descent will be: Rate of Descent (ft/min) = 6.6 % x 185 kt x 6080 / 6000 = 1 237 ft/min, which is very close to 1 220 ft/min.

content.question: In navigation we assume that the shape of earth is..

key_points: Shape Of the Earth The Earth is almost completely round
The force of gravity would pull the Earth into a perfect sphere shape, but its fast rotation on its axis reduces the effect of gravity on the Equator
The Earth rotates rapidly every 24 h and the surface at the Equator moves os fast that the effect of gravity is reduced there
learning.explanation: Shape Of the Earth The Earth is almost completely round. The force of gravity would pull the Earth into a perfect sphere shape, but its fast rotation on its axis reduces the effect of gravity on the Equator. The Earth rotates rapidly every 24 h and the surface at the Equator moves os fast that the effect of gravity is reduced there. This reduced gravity causes the land around the Equator to bulge outwards by approximately 21 km, while making the land at the poles appear flattened. The Earth is, therefore, an irregularly shaped ellipsoid, which is flattened at the poles and bulges at the Equator. This is slightly squished shape is called geoid. For most navigational purposes the Earth is assumed to be a perfect sphere (for simplicity).

Given:

A pilot intends to fly a route from A to B, covering a distance of 80 NM and departing at 12:15. The flight is planned with a heading of 235°. After 40 NM and at 12:27 the aircraft is crossing a rail line, which runs 90° to the flight track. At 12:37 the pilot should be 1 nm left of the track but s/he is actually 3 NM to the right. What Heading should s/he fly to reach her/his intended destination and what will be the ETA?

key_points: With the information provided by the question text, we can calculate the aircraft’s ground speed
The aircraft departs at 12:15 and we know that at 12:27 (after 12 minutes), the aircraft has covered 40 NM
Ground speed = (40 ÷ 12) x 60 = 200 kt The off track error of 4 NM (1 NM + 3 NM) is recognized at 12:37
learning.explanation: With the information provided by the question text, we can calculate the aircraft’s ground speed. The aircraft departs at 12:15 and we know that at 12:27 (after 12 minutes), the aircraft has covered 40 NM. Ground speed = (40 ÷ 12) x 60 = 200 kt The off track error of 4 NM (1 NM + 3 NM) is recognized at 12:37. We need to calculate the distance along track and the TKE (Track Angle Error) at this position. Time from A to railroad track (40 NM) ⇒ 12:27 - 12:15 = 12 min Time from railroad track to 4 NM off track position ⇒ 12:37 - 12:27 = 10 min Time from A to 4 NM off track position ⇒ 12 min + 10 min = 22 min If the aircraft's ground speed is 200 kt, in 22 minutes, it will cover: (200 kt x 22 min) ÷ 60 = 73 NM Calculate the TKE (Track Angle Error) to give us the heading correction in order to parallel our intended track: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track TKE = (4 × 60) ÷ 73 TKE = 3° (approx.) If we alter our heading by 3.3° (towards the original track) we will parallel our original track. In order to re-join the original track, we must calculate the track correction for the distance to go: Distance to go = 80 NM - 73 NM = 7 NM TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track TKE = (4 × 60) ÷ 7 TKE = 34° (approx.) So turning 3° will parallel our track, and turning an extra 34° on top of that will direct us to the final destination. Therefore, 3° + 34° = 37º (approx.) would be the total alteration required (to re-join the original track). The deviation was to the right, therefore we must fly 37º to the left. Track = 235º - 37º = 198º The aircraft is 80 NM – 73 NM = 7 NM away from the destination. At 200 kt, it will cover 7 NM in 2 minutes. The destination will be reached at 12:37 + 2 min = 12:39

content.question: The circumference of the Earth is approximately...

key_points: The diameter of Earth depends on where you are measuring it from
The Earth is not a perfect sphere, and so it has a different diameter around the equator than it does from pole to pole
We know that at the Equator, 1º Longitude = 1NM
learning.explanation: The diameter of Earth depends on where you are measuring it from. The Earth is not a perfect sphere, and so it has a different diameter around the equator than it does from pole to pole. We know that at the Equator, 1º Longitude = 1NM. Based on that, the circumference of the Earth may be calculated as follows: Earth circumference at the Equator = 360º x 60 NM = 21 600 NM => 21 600 NM x 1.852 = 40 000 km Circumference = π x diameter (π = 3.14) 40 000 km = π x diameter diameter = 40 000 km ÷ π diameter = 12 732 km Alternatively, you can just remember that the Earth's circumference (the distance all the way around the equator) is approximately 40 000 km (21 600 NM) and its diameter (the distance from one side to the other through Earth's center) is roughly 12 700 km.

A pilot is planned to fly a track of 270°(T) towards ZVR VOR. At 10:20 UTC they plot their position and determine that they are on course. At 10:32 UTC, after having travelled for 60 NM, the pilot plots their position again and finds themselves 10 NM off-track towards the south. TAS: 280 kt
Forecast Wind: 150º/30 kt

Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 280 kt

Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 280 kt. Mark the wind velocity 30 kt down from the centre point. Initially, set the True Track to 270º under the "TRUE HEADING" index. Note that this heading would result in 5ºR drift and a track of 275º. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading plus the drift gives a track of 270º. This occurs at a heading of 265º with 5ºR drift. All this means is that, to counteract an expected drift of 5ºR, the aircraft flew a heading of 265º(T). However, after covering a distance of 60 NM, our track error angle is 10º left, meaning our track made good has been 260º (T) Calculating the difference between our heading and the track made good results in 5º to the left (265ºT to 260ºT). The average drift observed from 10:20 UTC to 10:32 UTC amounts to 5º to the left. Note: Drift or drift angle, is the angular difference between the track of the aircraft across and it's heading. Always remember that the drift angle is always measured with reference to the heading.

learning.explanation: When a magnetic needle is influenced only by the Earth’s magnetic field, it points to magnetic north. But, if the compass is installed in an aircraft, the Earth's magnetic field will be distorted by the metal and the electrical equipment around it and the needle now deviates slightly from magnetic north, indicating a direction of 000°, known as compass north. Deviation varies with magnetic latitude, aircraft heading and changes in aircraft electronic equipment. The difference between the direction of magnetic north and that of compass north is called "deviation". Deviation is measured in degrees and is described as "East" (+) or "West" (-). To determine whether the deviation should be added or subtracted, use the rhyme: “Deviation East - Compass Least“ “Deviation West - Compass Best“ According to the figure’s compass deviation card, to fly a magnetic heading of 300°, the aircraft must steer to a compass heading of 298°. content.question: An aircraft departs point A, intending to fly direct to point B, 140 NM away. After flying 18 minutes or 41 NM, the aircraft is 7 NM left of track.To regain the intended track in an equal amount of time, the heading of the aircraft must be changed:

learning.explanation: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning. If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track. The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good. The difference between them is called track error (TE). The angle at which we want to close to come back to the planned track is the closing angle (CA). The CA will depend how much further we want to rejoin the planned track. The 1 in 60 rule can be used to calculate the TE and the CA. TE = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 TE = (7/41) x 60 = 10º The same 1 in 60 rule can be applied to calculate the CA. CA = (distance off-track/distance at which we want to rejoin track) x 60 CA = (7/41) x 60 = 10º With both TE and CA, we can determine by how much heading change we should apply to regain track: Heading change = TE + CA = 10º + 10º = 20º R The aircraft is left off-track, the aircraft must fly right to regain track.

learning.explanation: MAGNETIC VARIATION The earth behaves as though a huge permanent magnet were situated near the centre producing a magnetic field over the surface. The poles of this hypothetical earth-magnet do not lie on the earth’s spin axis, this lack of symmetry giving rise to magnetic variation - the angular difference between the True North (TN) and the Magnetic North (MN). Variation is designated west or east depending on whether the magnetic pole lies to the west or to the east of true north: - If the Magnetic North is west of the True North, westerly variation, the magnetic direction will have a higher angular value than the true direction. - If the Magnetic North is east of the True North, easterly variation, the magnetic direction will have a lower angular value than the true direction. This is known as compass deviation and can result in deviation either east or west of magnetic north by an amount, which depends on the aeroplane’s heading and latitude. Deviation (-) West – Compass Best Deviation (+) East – Compass Least Any deviation can be analysed and resolved into components acting along the aeroplane’s major axes. The causes of the deviation are analysed and corrected for by carrying out a compass swing, although some residual deviation remains, and recording them on a deviation card. To obtain a True Heading from the Compass Heading: Use the acronym C-D-M-V-T, and replace the values you are given in the question: From left to right, magnetic deviation W is subtracted from Compass Heading to get Magnetic Heading and magnetic variation E is added to Compass Heading to get Magnetic Heading. learning.explanation: The poles of the Earth's magnetic field are close to the geographic poles, which lie on the axis of the Earth's rotation, but not coincident, so that a compass pointing to magnetic north will not point exactly at the geographic north pole. By analogy with their navigational use, the words dead reckoning are also used to mean the process of estimating the value of any variable quantity by using an earlier value and adding whatever changes have occurred in the meantime. Often, this usage implies that the changes are not known accurately. The earlier value and the changes may be measured or calculated quantities. content.question: You are flying from point A to point B, a distance of 75 NM, on a heading of 288°. After 45 NM you have diverged 4° right off track. What heading correction should be made to reach position B?

key_points: Two heading corrections must be made to reach position B: The aircraft have diverged 4o right off track, so the first correction must be a left turn by the same amount of degrees, 4o, to parallel with the desired track, following a heading of: 288° - 4o = 284°
But, after this correction the aircraft will be just following the desired track in parallel and will never reach position B
The distance-off track is required for the second correction, which is given by the 1:60 rule based formula: (Distance off track / Miles travelled) = (Degrees to parallel / 60)
learning.explanation: Two heading corrections must be made to reach position B: The aircraft have diverged 4o right off track, so the first correction must be a left turn by the same amount of degrees, 4o, to parallel with the desired track, following a heading of: 288° - 4o = 284°. But, after this correction the aircraft will be just following the desired track in parallel and will never reach position B. The distance-off track is required for the second correction, which is given by the 1:60 rule based formula: (Distance off track / Miles travelled) = (Degrees to parallel / 60). Solving for Distance off track we get: Distance off track = Degrees to parallel x Miles travelled / 60 = 4o x 45 NM / 60 = 3 NM. The second correction that must be so as to intercept position B, is given by the 1:60 rule based formula: (Distance off track / Miles to go) = (Degrees to intercept / 60). Solving for Degrees to intercept we get: Degrees to intercept = (Distance off track x 60) / Miles to go = (3 NM x 60) / (75 NM - 45 NM) = 6o left. Thus, the total correction that must be made is: 4o left + 6o left = 10o Left onto 288o - 10o = 278o heading.

An aircraft flies over a small lake which is located some degrees to the left of the planned track. Given the following information and using the 1 in 60 rule, what is the drift angle of this aircraft (rounded to the nearest whole degree)?

Off-track distance between the lake and the track: 2.4 NM

key_points: The aircraft flying with a TAS of 100 kt and experiencing a tailwind of 15 kt, will have a Groundspeed of: TAS + Tailwind component = 100 kt + 15 kt = 115 kt
The 1:60 rule states that: "For each degree of drift angle you will be one NM off-track having travelled 60 NM along track"
If you are only 20 NM along track, every one degree of drift angle relates to one third of a NM
learning.explanation: The aircraft flying with a TAS of 100 kt and experiencing a tailwind of 15 kt, will have a Groundspeed of: TAS + Tailwind component = 100 kt + 15 kt = 115 kt. The 1:60 rule states that: "For each degree of drift angle you will be one NM off-track having travelled 60 NM along track". If you are only 20 NM along track, every one degree of drift angle relates to one third of a NM. If so, 2 NM off-track must equate to a 6º drift angle and 3 NM off-track must equate to a 9º drift angle. For this question, the aircraft experiences the 2.4 NM off-track distance between the lake and the track, 11 minutes from the previous waypoint. So, the distance from the previous waypoint until the aircraft flies above the small lake is: Distance = GS x Flight time = 115 kt x 11/60 hr = 21 NM. Applying the 1:60 rule, an aircraft which is off-track 2.4 NM after 60 NM, will have a drift angle of 2.4º. Thus, after 21 NM, the aircraft will have a drift angle of: 2.4º x 2.86 (60/21)= 7º (rounded).

learning.explanation: No calculations are required for this question, because it asks for TAS and CAS “at some point during climb” and not at a specific altitude during climb. A usefool tool in determining the changing relationship between EAS, CAS, TAS and Mach in climbs and descents, below the tropopause, is the ECTM graphs. CAS can be considered to be identical to IAS. The ECTM graphs are used to determine what happens to the other three speeds when climbing or descending, whilst holding one speed constant, by drawing initially the parameter that is to be held constant as a vertical line and drawing, later, connecting lines to the remaining letters. The lines are always in the sequence "ECTM", in the standard atmosphere and the speed held constant is drawn vertically. During climb with a constant Mach number, both TAS and CAS decrease. Thus, since at the beginning of the descent the instruments' cross-check shows a CAS of 264 kt and a TAS of 365 kt, at a higher altitude during the climb, both TAS and CAS speeds are expected to be lower. Therefore, the option that gives both a CAS less than 264 kt and a TAS less than 365 kt is TAS at 356 kt and CAS at 233 kt.

content.question: An aircraft flies from A to B, the ground distance is 78 NM. After 48 NM the pilot notices a cross-track error angle of 4° to the right. In order to directly reach point B, by using the “1 in-60” rule, the pilot should change the heading to the left by...

key_points: By altering the heading towards the original track (to the left) by 4°, the aircraft will fly parallel to the original track
To re-join the original track at A, we must find the track correction to reach B
For that, we need to find the distance off-track first
learning.explanation: By altering the heading towards the original track (to the left) by 4°, the aircraft will fly parallel to the original track. To re-join the original track at A, we must find the track correction to reach B. For that, we need to find the distance off-track first. We have been given the Track Angle Error (TKE) of 4° to the right. We can determine the distance off track by applying the following formula: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track 4° = (distance off track × 60) ÷ 48 distance off track = (4° x 48) ÷ 60 = 3 NM The correction to reach B will be: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance to go TKE = (3 × 60) ÷ 30 TKE = 6° ⇒ Turning 4° to the left will lead us to fly parallel to the original track. Turning an extra 6° to the left will direct us to "B". 4° + 6° = 10° to the left to go direct to "B".

Navigation by Dead Reckoning is part of the basic training for pilots. With the introduction of modern navigational techniques such as GPS and conventional radio navigational aids, this may seem outdated technique. Accuracy of DR depends on: Time elapsed since last fix; Accuracy of the wind velocity used; Accuracy of headings and airspeeds; Skill and knowledge of the pilot. Reasons for why we continue to teach Dead Reckoning: 1. Creation of a Dead Reckoning encourages the pilot to consider the safest and most economical flightpath, potential threats and eventual consequences of navigational errors. 2. It is an acceptable and approved mean of navigation. Dead Reckoning can be used to navigate under Visual Flight Rules without having to rely on a radio or other navigational aids. 3. It is fail-safe mean of navigation. DR does not rely on any navigational aid, it is therefore a valuable contingency navigation method, even if the the plan is to fly with. learning.explanation: There are multiple methods available to address this question, and the choice among them depends on personal preference. Method 1: The Height difference is: 18 000 ft - 3 000 ft = 15 000 ft The Groundspeed is: TAS + Tailwind component = 130 kt + 30 kt = 160 kt 25 NM / 160 kt = 0.15625 hours 0.15625 hours × 60 minutes/hour ≈ 9.4 minutes 15 000 ft / 9.4 minutes ≈ 1 600 ft/min Method 2: The following formula can be used: Height difference (ft) = Glidepath Angle(o) x Covered Distance (ft) / 60. The Height difference is: 18 000 ft - 3 000 ft = 15 000 ft. So, solving for Glidepath Angle, we get: Glidepath Angle(o) = (Height difference (ft) x 60) / Covered Distance (ft) = 15 000 ft x 60 / (25 x 6080 ) ft = 5.9o. The Groundspeed is: TAS + Tailwind component = 130 kt + 30 kt = 160 kt. Thus, ROD = (Glide Angle/60) x (Groundspeed/60) x 6080 = (5.9/60) x (160/60) x 6080 = 1 594 ft/min, which is very close to 1 600 ft/min. Method 3: For a 3o glideslope angle only, the following formula states: ROD = 5 x GS = 5 x 160 = 800 fpm. learning.explanation: The aircraft flying with a GS of 140 kt, experiences a left off-track deviation of 4 NM after: Distance = GS x Time = 140 kt x 12/60 hr = 28 NM. Therefore; Distance along track = 32.5 NM + 2.5 NM = 35 NM Calculate the TKE (Track Angle Error) to give us the heading correction in order to parallel our intended track: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track TKE = (3 × 60) ÷ 35 TKE = 5° If we alter our heading by 5° (towards the original track) we will parallel our original track. In order to re-join the original track, we must calculate the track correction for the distance to go: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance to go TKE = (3 × 60) ÷ 10 TKE = 18º The result is greater than 15º and therefore inaccurate. Trigonometry: tan α = 3 NM / 10 NM α = tan-1 (3/10) ≈ 17º So turning 5° will parallel our track, and turning an extra 17° on top of that will direct us to the final destination. Therefore, 5° + 17° = 22º would be the total alteration required (to re-join the original track). The deviation was to the left; therefore we must fly 22º to the right.

learning.explanation: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning. If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track. 1. The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good. The difference between them is called track error (TE). 2. content.question:
The Earth's spin axis is inclined to the plane of the ecliptic. What effect does that have on the duration of daylight at Cambridge (52°N, 000°E) compared with that at La Palma in the Canary islands (29°N, 018°W) on the same day?
Cambridge will have (1) __ hours of daylight on the 1st July and (2) __ hours of daylight on the 1st January.

key_points: The ecliptic is the name given to the apparent path of the Sun on the celestial sphere
It also refers to the plane of this path and the orbit of the Earth around the Sun and the apparent orbit of the Sun around the Earth
The axis of rotation of the Earth is inclined to this orbital path at an angle of about 66
learning.explanation: The ecliptic is the name given to the apparent path of the Sun on the celestial sphere. It also refers to the plane of this path and the orbit of the Earth around the Sun and the apparent orbit of the Sun around the Earth. The axis of rotation of the Earth is inclined to this orbital path at an angle of about 66.5o, which means that the angle between the plane of ecliptic and the Earth’s equator is 23.5o. When we are at the Equator, the daylight does not vary significantly over the year, whereas if we are near the poles, the difference between summer and winter is very dramatic. When looking at total sunlight received, the poles generally have lower sunlight, because even in their summer, there is much lower land area relative to the equator. The tilt of the Earth of the Earth’s axis also means that in extreme northern and southern latitudes, there will be times of the year in winter when the Sun does not rise and times in summer when it does not set. The time of sunrise and sunset changes very little day by day except at high latitudes. The time of sunrise and sunset varies with latitude and time of year higher latitudes experience longer days in the summer and shorter days in the winter. The reason for the variation of the duration of daylight throughout the year is the inclination of the Earth’s axis of rotation to the ecliptic. Therefore, Cambridge, which has a relatively high latitude (52oN) will have more hours of daylight on the 1st July and fewer hours of daylight on the 1st January.

key_points: The heights on the glideslope can be calculted using the formula: Height difference (ft) = Glidepath Angle(o) x Distance to go (ft) / 60

So, solving for Distance to go, we get: Distance to go (ft) = (Height difference (ft) x 60) / Glidepath angle (o). The aircraft descends from cruise altitude 4500ft to the traffic pattern altitude 1500 ft, thus the height difference is 3000 ft. Therefore, the horizontal distance covered during the descent is: Distance to go (ft) = (3000 ft x 60) / 3o = 60,000 ft or 60,000ft / 6,080 = 9.86 NM, rounded 10 NM. The aircraft's average Rate of Descent is 850 ft/min, which means that it loses 850 ft in 1 min. Therefore, the aircraft loses 3000 ft in: 3000ft / 850 ft/min = 3.5 minutes or 3 minutes 30 seconds. learning.explanation: You can find the following formulas in the learning objectives of General Navigation (061): Rate of descent (ft/min) = Glide path (degrees) x Ground speed (NM/min) x 100 Rate of descent (ft/min) = Glide path (%) x Ground speed (kt) As the True Airspeed is 110 knots and there's a 15-knot tailwind component, the resulting Ground Speed can be calculated as follows: Ground Speed = True Airspeed + Tailwind Component Ground Speed = 110 knots + 15 knots Ground Speed = 125 knots Converting Ground Speed to nautical miles per minute: Ground Speed in NM/min = 125 knots / 60 Ground Speed in NM/min ≈ 2.08 NM/min Given the Ground Speed of approximately 2.08 NM/min and a glide path angle of 3.5°, the rate of descent can be calculated as follows: Rate of descent (ft/min) = Glide path (degrees) x Ground speed (NM/min) x 100 Rate of descent (ft/min) = 3.5° × 2.08 NM/min × 100 ft/NM Rate of Descent ≈ 730 ft/min Alternatively, you can use the following method: Rate of descent = 5 x Ground Speed x (Glide path / 3) Rate of descent = 5 x 125 x (3.5/3) Rate of descent = 729.2 ft/min

key_points: No calculations are required for this question, because it asks for TAS and Mach speed “at some point during climb” and not at a specific altitude during your climb
A usefool tool in determining the changing relationship between EAS, CAS, TAS and Mach in climbs and descents below the tropopause, is the ECTM graphs
CAS can be considered to be identical to IAS
learning.explanation: No calculations are required for this question, because it asks for TAS and Mach speed “at some point during climb” and not at a specific altitude during your climb. A usefool tool in determining the changing relationship between EAS, CAS, TAS and Mach in climbs and descents below the tropopause, is the ECTM graphs. CAS can be considered to be identical to IAS. The ECTM graphs are used to determine what happens to the other three speeds when climbing or descending, whilst holding one speed constant, by drawing initially the parameter that is to be held constant as a vertical line and drawing, later, connecting lines to the remaining letters. The lines are always in the sequence "ECTM", in the standard atmosphere and the speed held constant is drawn vertically. During climb with a constant CAS, both TAS and Mach speed increase. Thus, since at the beginning of the climb the instruments' cross-check shows TAS at 336 kt and Mach speed 0.55, at FL280 both TAS and Mach speeds are expected to be higher. Therefore, the only option that gives both TAS and Mach speed higher than 336 kt and 0.55 correspondingly, is TAS 357 kt and Mach 0.59.

content.question: A pilot plans to fly from an accurate fix at 22:00z with a heading of 175°. The track is planned to fly directly overhead an aerodrome after 37 NM, then continue in the same direction for another 50 NM after that. At 22:14 the aircraft actually passes 5 NM to the right of the aerodrome. What should the pilot make the new heading to reach the next turning point 50 NM away, and what is their new ETA at that turning point?

key_points: The aircraft covers the distance of 37 NM, from the fixpoint to an aerodrome, between 22:00 and 22:14, i
e
in 14 minutes
learning.explanation: The aircraft covers the distance of 37 NM, from the fixpoint to an aerodrome, between 22:00 and 22:14, i.e. in 14 minutes. So its actual Groundspeed is: GS = Distance / Time = 37 NM / (14/60) = 158 kt. Thus, it covers the distance of 50 NM from the aerodrome to the turning point in: Time = Distance / GS = 50 NM / 158 = 0.31 hr or 19 min. Therefore, the aircraft's Estimated Time of Arrival at the turning point will be: 22:14 + 19 min = 22:33. But the aircraft is not above overhead the aerodrome as planned, but 5 NM right off it, because the wind is not as forecast. Using your Navigation/Flight computer follow the steps below: Firstly, find the Track Error Angle, which is also the degrees to parallel: Place the distance off track 5 NM (50) over the distance gone 37 NM and read over the 60 marker the degrees to parallel 8.1o (81) on the outer scale. Secondly, find the degrees to intercept at the next turning point: Place the distance off track 5 NM (50) over the distance to go 50 NM and read over the 60 marker the degrees to get back to track at the turning point 6o (60) on the outer scale. Thus, the total correction to the heading must be: 8.1o + 6o = 14.1o. And since the aircraft is off track to the right, the total correction to the heading must be to the left. Therefore, the heading to intercept the turning point must be: 175o - 14.1o = 160.9o, which is close to 161o.

content.question: A flight leg of 90 NM is planned from A to B via an intermediate point C overhead a railway intersection. The planned heading is 037⁰T and the planned GS is 135 kt. After 12 minutes the pilot notices that he/she is 3 NM ahead and 3NM left of the railway intersection, instead of 1 NM right, as expected. Find the required heading to reach at B.

key_points: The planned GS is 135 kt and after 12 min from A the pilot expected to be overhead the railway intersection, point C
Thus, the distance from A to C is: Planned GS / Planned A - C = (135 kt x 12 min) / 60 = 27 NM
But, the aircraft is 3 NM ahead of point C, thus: 27 NM + 3 NM = 30 NM from A
learning.explanation: The planned GS is 135 kt and after 12 min from A the pilot expected to be overhead the railway intersection, point C. Thus, the distance from A to C is: Planned GS / Planned A - C = (135 kt x 12 min) / 60 = 27 NM. But, the aircraft is 3 NM ahead of point C, thus: 27 NM + 3 NM = 30 NM from A. Thus, the remaining distance after C is: 90 NM - 30 NM = 60 NM. The off - course deviation after 30 NM with reference to point C is: 3 NM left + 1 NM right = 4 NM left. Using your Flight/Nav computer, the corrections that must be made to the heading are: Degrees to parallel: Align distance off, 4 NM (40) outer scale, with distance travelled, 30 NM inner scale. Above the black arrow (60), read the degrees to parallel: 8° (80 ) on the outer scale. Degrees to intercept position B: Align distance off, 4 NM (40) outer scale, with distance to go, 60 NM inner scale. Above the black arrow (60), read the degrees to intercept: 4° (40) on outer scale. Thus, the total heading correction to proceed directly to position B is: 8° + 4° = 12°. And since the deviation is to the left, the heading correction must be to the right. Therefore, the required heading to reach at B is: 037⁰T + 12° = 049⁰T.

content.question: What scenario will give the greatest difference between nautical air miles and ground miles?

key_points: Nautical Air Miles (NAM) is the air distance flown at a given True Airspeed (TAS) and is given by the formula: NAM = TAS x TIME
Nautical Ground Miles (NGM) is the ground distance covered over the Earth's surface at a given Groundspeed (GS) and is given by the formula: NGM = GS x TIME
The air distance (NAM) is equal to the ground distance (NGM) in nil wind conditions
learning.explanation: Nautical Air Miles (NAM) is the air distance flown at a given True Airspeed (TAS) and is given by the formula: NAM = TAS x TIME. Nautical Ground Miles (NGM) is the ground distance covered over the Earth's surface at a given Groundspeed (GS) and is given by the formula: NGM = GS x TIME. The air distance (NAM) is equal to the ground distance (NGM) in nil wind conditions. It is important to note that, as altitude increases, the air distance increases and so does the difference between the air distance and the ground distance - this is due to the curvature of the Earth. The headwind or tailwind component, when applied to the TAS, will give the GS: GS = TAS +/- Tailwind/Headwind. NAM - NGM is greatest when there is a headwind.

content.question: An aircraft departs point A (26°06'N,004°11'E) and flies directly south for 500 NM to point B. From point B, the aircraft flies directly east for 500 NM to point C. The coordinates of point C are…

key_points: The aircraft initially flies south, so it flies along the meridian 004°11'E
Along a meridian "1 minute of latitude equals to 1 NM"
Thus, a distance of 500 NM along a meridian corresponds to 500' change of latitude or 8° 20'
learning.explanation: The aircraft initially flies south, so it flies along the meridian 004°11'E. Along a meridian "1 minute of latitude equals to 1 NM". Thus, a distance of 500 NM along a meridian corresponds to 500' change of latitude or 8° 20'. Therefore, as it flies south on the northern hemisphere, its latitude will decrease, provided that it does not cross the Equator. Its new latitude at B point, after 500 NM south off A point, will be: 26°06'N - 8° 20' = 17°46'N. After B point, the aircraft continues eastwards (i.e. along the same parallel of latitude) for 500 NM along the 17°46'N parallel of latitude. The distance along a parallel of latitude is called "Departure" and is given by the formula: Departure(NM) = Change of Longitude(min) x cos Lat. Solving for Change of Longitude we get: Change of Longitude(min) = Departure(NM) / cos Lat = 500 NM / cos 17°46' = 525 or 8° 45'. Therefore, its new longitude, after 500 NM east off B point, will be: 004°11' + 8° 45' = 012°56' E. Finally, C position's coordinates will be: 17°46'N 012°56' E.

content.question: The inclination of the Earth's spin axis in relation to the plane of rotation around the Sun is the cause of the variable amount of (1) _____ and the changing duration of (2) _____ throughout the year at mid and high latitudes.

key_points: Insolation is a measure of solar radiation energy received on a given surface area in a given time
Solar energy is created at the core of the Sun and hits the Earth with an intensity depending on its angle of arrival

The angle of arrival at any point, as a result of the Earth's axis inclination in relation to the plane of rotation, is dependent on its latitude, the season, as the Earth axis tilts in relation to the Sun and the time of day
learning.explanation: Insolation is a measure of solar radiation energy received on a given surface area in a given time. Solar energy is created at the core of the Sun and hits the Earth with an intensity depending on its angle of arrival. The angle of arrival at any point, as a result of the Earth's axis inclination in relation to the plane of rotation, is dependent on its latitude, the season, as the Earth axis tilts in relation to the Sun and the time of day. Also, the Earth's axis inclination in relation to the plane of rotation around the Sun, is responsible for the changing duration of the daylight throughout the year at mid and high latitudes. When the northern hemisphere is tilted most towards the Sun, it experiences northern hemisphere summer, when it tilts most away, it experiences northern hemisphere winter, but southern hemisphere summer. The tilt of the Earth’s axis also accounts for longer nights in winter and longer days in summer.

content.question: An aircraft is flying at a pressure altitude of 10 000 feet in conditions where the temperature is -15°C (ISA). If the recorded ground speed is 485 knots and there is a headwind component of 25 knots, what is the True Airspeed (TAS) of the aircraft?

key_points: Learning Objectives 061
learning.explanation: Learning Objectives 061.01.05.04.02: Apply HWC and TWC to determine GS from TAS and vice versa. The question provides a lot of data, but to find the True Airspeed (TAS), we only need the Ground Speed (GS) and the wind component. With a headwind, the TAS is higher than the GS because the wind is slowing you down. Therefore, you add the headwind component to the GS. With a tailwind, the TAS is lower than the GS because the wind is pushing you faster. Therefore, you subtract the tailwind component from the GS. Here's the formula to calculate TAS: TAS = GS ± Headwind/Tailwind Component - Use the plus sign if it’s a headwind (wind blowing against the direction of travel). - Use the minus sign if it’s a tailwind (wind blowing in the same direction as travel). Given: Ground Speed (GS) = 485 knots Headwind Component = 25 knots Since it's a headwind, you add the headwind component to the ground speed to find the TAS. TAS = GS + Headwind Component TAS = 485 kt + 25 kt TAS = 510 kt

options.A: Rate of climb/descent (feet/min) = Arctg (Altitude difference (ft) ÷ Ground distance covered (in ft))

key_points: Descent rate using the Ground speed approximation formula: Rate of climb/descent (ft/min) = [Descent rate (ft/NM) x Ground speed (knots)] ÷ 60; or Rate of climb/descent (ft/min) = Descent rate (%) x Ground speed (knots) Example: Ground speed is 110kt, and descent rate is standard 5
Note that the descent rate value can be approximated using only 5% instead of 5
learning.explanation: Descent rate using the Ground speed approximation formula: Rate of climb/descent (ft/min) = [Descent rate (ft/NM) x Ground speed (knots)] ÷ 60; or Rate of climb/descent (ft/min) = Descent rate (%) x Ground speed (knots) Example: Ground speed is 110kt, and descent rate is standard 5.2%. Note that the descent rate value can be approximated using only 5% instead of 5.2%. Vertical speed = 5 x 110 = 550ft/min, (if we use 5.2% instead, vertical speed will be 572 ft/min → less than 5% error).

content.question: An aircraft circles the Earth along the parallel of 88°N at a groundspeed of 150 kt. If the actual time of departure from point A is 08:25, the ETA at point A is approximately…

key_points: "An aircraft circles the earth" means that the aircraft flies for 360o Change of Longitude, so the departure and destination point is the same
Thus, its Change of Longitude in minutes is 360o or 360o x 60' = 21600'
The distance along a parallel of latitude is given by the formula: Departure (NM) = Change of Longitude (min) x Cos of Latitude = 21600' x Cos 88o = 753
learning.explanation: "An aircraft circles the earth" means that the aircraft flies for 360o Change of Longitude, so the departure and destination point is the same. Thus, its Change of Longitude in minutes is 360o or 360o x 60' = 21600'. The distance along a parallel of latitude is given by the formula: Departure (NM) = Change of Longitude (min) x Cos of Latitude = 21600' x Cos 88o = 753.8 NM. The Flight Time is given by the formula: Time = Distance / Groundspeed = 753.8 NM / 150 kt = 5.02 hrs. Therefore, the ETA at point A is approximately: 08:25 + 5 hrs = 13:25.

content.question:
You are descending to FL180 from FL310, the wind is as follows:
FL310 230/55
FL290 240/45
FL250 190/40
FL180 200/30
For flight planning purposes, what is the most appropriate wind to use?

key_points: WV used for climb problems is the WV at the altitude 2/3 of the cruising altitude
WV used for descent problems is the WV at the altitude 1/2 of the descent altitude
In this scenario, the halfway down the descent point is between FL310 and FL180 is at FL245
learning.explanation: WV used for climb problems is the WV at the altitude 2/3 of the cruising altitude. WV used for descent problems is the WV at the altitude 1/2 of the descent altitude. In this scenario, the halfway down the descent point is between FL310 and FL180 is at FL245. We need to perform interpolation between the wind data at FL250 and FL180 to estimate the values at FL245. The interpolated values are approximately 191º/39 kt. While none of the available options precisely match these interpolated values, the most suitable choice from the provided answers would be 205º/40 kt for wind speed. To break down the interpolation: Interpolation: FL250: 190/40 FL180: 200/30 During a 7 000 ft descent (from 25 000 ft to 18 000 ft), the wind direction veered by 10º. Therefore, in a 500 ft interval, the wind would change by approximately 1º (191º). Similarly, during the same 7 000 ft descent, the wind speed decreased by 10 kt. Hence, in a 500 ft interval, the wind speed would decrease by roughly 1 kt (39 kt). Consequently, the most appropriate wind estimate, given these considerations, would be 205º/40 kt.

The difference of latitude or change of latitude is the angle between the two parallels, measured at the centre of the Earth. The latitudes between A and B point are in the same hemisphere, so subtract to get the change of latitude: 37°00'00'' - 21°00'00'' = 16°00'00''. Given the following information, calculate the wind velocity:

TAS: 480 kt
Track: 240°T

(2) Place the centre of the rotating disk on the value representing the true airspeed (480 kt)

Follow the steps detailed below in order to find unknown wind: (1) Place the heading (233º) under the true index. (2) Place the centre of the rotating disk on the value representing the true airspeed (480 kt). (3) Determine the drift: Drift or drift angle, is the angular difference between the track of the aircraft and its heading. Keep in mind, to determine the drift the reference is heading to track. content.question:
An aircraft starts to climb from 4 000 ft with a Groundspeed of 220 kt to 8 000 ft with a constant Rate of Climb of 1 500 ft/min. Given the following information, how long will it take to climb and what Ground distance will be covered?
Average climb TAS: 240 kt
Wind at 8000 ft: 200º(T)/45 kt
Approximate Track during the climb: 250ºT

key_points: According to the Learning Objectives the Average W/V used for: Climb problems is the W/V at the altitude 2/3 of the cruising altitude
Descent problems is the W/V at the altitude 1/2 of the descent altitude
learning.explanation: According to the Learning Objectives the Average W/V used for: Climb problems is the W/V at the altitude 2/3 of the cruising altitude. Descent problems is the W/V at the altitude 1/2 of the descent altitude. 1. The aircaft climbs from 4 000 ft to 8 000 ft. The 2/3 of the cruising altitude is at: [2/3 x (8 000 - 4 000)] ft + 4 000 ft= 6 667 ft. 2. With the data given, we cannot find the W/V at 4 000 ft and interpolate with the W/V at 8 000 ft for the 2/3 of the cruising altitude, but we can find through the flight/nav computer, the GS at 8 000 ft and interpolate with the GS given at 4 000 ft for the 2/3: Set wind direction to 200º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 240 kt. Mark the wind velocity 45 kt down from the centre point. Initially, set the True Track to 250º under the "TRUE HEADING" index. Note that this heading would result in 9ºR drift and a track of 259º. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading plus the drift gives a track of 250º. This occurs at a heading of 241º with 8ºR drift. The groundspeed at 8 000 ft for this track is approximately 208 kt. 3. After interpolation, the GS at 2/3 of the cruising altitude (6 667 ft) is: 212 kt. 4. The time to climb from 4 000 ft to 8 000 ft is: Height difference / ROC = (8 000 ft - 4 000 ft) / 1 500 fpm = 2.67 min. 5. The Ground distance covered during the climb is: GS x Time = 212 kt x 2.67/60 hr = 9.434 NM.(9.4 is the closest)

content.question: The main purpose of DR navigation is to…

options.B: improve the accuracy of GPS positions.
options.C: obtain, with reasonable accuracy, the aircrafts position between IRS fixes.
options.D: obtain, with reasonable accuracy, the aircraft’s position between fixes or in the absence of fixes.

key_points: Navigation by Dead Reckoning is part of the basic training for pilots
Based in the calculation of the position of airplane based in the direction and the ground distance traveled from a determined point
With the introduction of modern navigational techniques such as GPS and conventional radio navigational aids, this may seem outdated technique
learning.explanation: Navigation by Dead Reckoning is part of the basic training for pilots. Based in the calculation of the position of airplane based in the direction and the ground distance traveled from a determined point. With the introduction of modern navigational techniques such as GPS and conventional radio navigational aids, this may seem outdated technique. Reasons for why we continue to teach Dead Reckoning: 1. Creation of a Dead Reckoning encourages the pilot to consider the safest and most economical flightpath, potential threats and eventual consequences of navigational errors. 2. It is an acceptable and approved mean of navigation. Dead Reckoning can be used to navigate under Visual Flight Rules without having to rely on a radio or other navigational aids. 3. It is fail-safe mean of navigation. DR does not rely on any navigational aid, it is therefore a valuable contingency navigation method, even if the the plan is to fly with. Reference to a GPS or other navigation aid.

Thus, its planned fuel consumption is: 119 kg / (53/60) hr = 134.7 kg/hr. content.question: An aircraft is flying at FL200, where the Outside Air Temperature is ISA -7°C, with a CAS of 150 kt. Calculate the approximate TAS by applying the rule of thumb for TAS calculations.

key_points: According to the rule of thumb for TAS calculations: TAS increases by 2% of the CAS for each 1 000 ft of altitude
For an aircraft flying at FL200, the TAS will increase by: (20 000 ft/1 000 ft) x 2% of 150 kt = 40 % of 150 kt = 60 kt
Thus, the TAS at FL200 will be: 150 kt + 60 kt = 210 kt NOTE: Using your flight computer for airspeed correction will yield a distinct True Airspeed (TAS) value
learning.explanation: According to the rule of thumb for TAS calculations: TAS increases by 2% of the CAS for each 1 000 ft of altitude. For an aircraft flying at FL200, the TAS will increase by: (20 000 ft/1 000 ft) x 2% of 150 kt = 40 % of 150 kt = 60 kt. Thus, the TAS at FL200 will be: 150 kt + 60 kt = 210 kt NOTE: Using your flight computer for airspeed correction will yield a distinct True Airspeed (TAS) value. In cases where the question instructs you to apply the rule of thumb, you must adhere to this instruction, even though it doesn't consider the temperature.

content.question: A pilot is planning a VFR flight across steep, mountainous terrain. Due to airspace restrictions, the flight will be relatively low above the terrain. Restrictions in VFR navigation in such circumstances can include...

options.A: a shorter time to see navigation features on the near side of valleys, compared to when flying over a flat landscape.
options.B: a shorter visual range for navigation features that are down slope, compared to the visual range for similar features situated on flat land.
options.C: poor visibility in the valleys when the flight is taking place at mid-day.
options.D: difficulty in identifying navigation features that are situated on ridges.

key_points: During your VFR route planning, look for distinctive areas of water, areas (such as valleys) with distinctive ground features or line features (railway lines, motorways, rivers, etc
But, before selecting the route and altitude, check if hills, ridges or woods in the vicinity of the above features hide them or shorten the period of time they are visible from the air
learning.explanation: During your VFR route planning, look for distinctive areas of water, areas (such as valleys) with distinctive ground features or line features (railway lines, motorways, rivers, etc.). But, before selecting the route and altitude, check if hills, ridges or woods in the vicinity of the above features hide them or shorten the period of time they are visible from the air. So, he/she is not able to see features on the near side of the valley, until he/she is over the ridge, thus he/she has a shorter time to see navigation features on the near side of valleys, compared to when flying over a flat landscape.

content.question:
A pilot flies from Aerodrome A to Aerodrome B. The return flight to Aerodrome A is scheduled after a quick turn-around. Assume the same wind conditions for both flights. Given the following information, calculate the average groundspeed for the return.

learning.explanation: Groundspeed (GS) is the speed of the aeroplane over the Earth's surface and equal to: True Airspeed + TWC or True Airspeed - HWC. Since the question assumes the same wind conditions for both flights, then the HWC from Aerodrome A to Aerodrome B, switches into a TWC from Aerodrome B to Aerodrome A of equal magnitude: 25 kt. Thus, the Groundspeed from Aerodrome B to Aerodrome A will be: Average TAS for the return flight + TWC = 145 kt + 25 kt = 170 kt.
