content.question:
An aircraft is flying a distance of 50 NM from A to B. After 15 minutes of flying with the planned TAS and TH the aircraft is 3 NM South of the intended track and 2.5 NM ahead of the dead reckoning position. Determine the approximate correction angle on the heading to reach destination B from this position, given:
True course in the flight log: 090°
Forecast wind: 225° (T) / 15 kts
TAS: 120 kts

key_points: Solving from Heading (HDG), knowing WV, TAS and required track
Set wind direction to 225º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top
Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 120 kt
learning.explanation: Solving from Heading (HDG), knowing WV, TAS and required track. Set wind direction to 225º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 120 kt. Mark the wind velocity 15 kt down from the centre point. Initially, set the True Track to 090º under the "TRUE HEADING" index. Note that this heading would result in 4ºL drift and a track of 086º. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading minus the drift gives a track of 090º. This occurs at a heading of 094º with 5ºL drift. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 130 kt. GS = 130 kts Planned track distance flown = 130 x 15 min = 32.5 NM => This distance is based on the forecast wind, but the exercise states that the aircraft is 2.5 ahead of the dead reckoning position, actual position = 32.5 + 2.5 = 35 NM. Calculate the TKE (Track Angle Error) to give us the heading correction in order to parallel our intended track: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track TKE = (3 × 60) ÷ 35 TKE = 5° If we alter our heading by 5° (towards the original track) we will parallel our original track. In order to re-join the original track, we must calculate the track correction for the distance to go: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance to go TKE = (3 × 60) ÷ 15 TKE = 12º So turning 5° will parallel our track, and turning an extra 12° on top of that will direct us to the final destination. Therefore, 5° + 12° = 17º would be the total alteration required (to re-join the original track).

A VFR flight is navigated by dead reckoning. When flying from point B to point C, the position of the aircraft is fixed, and a change of heading is calculated. The 1:60 rule is used to determine the heading from the fix position in order to get back on track in approximately the same time it took from point B to the fix position. With the given information, what heading is required?
Planned DR heading from B to C: 313°
Cross track error: 3 NM left
Along track distance from B: 45 NM

key_points: AS in the attachment: Dead Reckoning Calculations: Cross track error: 3 NM left Planned DR eating from B to C: 313˚ Along track distance from B: 45 NM (from B to fix position) Written in the question (The 1: 60 rule is used to determine the heading from the fix position to be back on track in approximately the same time it has taken from position B to the fix position) TKE = (distance off track / distance along track) x 60 = (3 / 45) x 60 = 4˚ As the fix in the middle of the track between B to C: Correction to regain track = 4˚ x 2 = 8˚ to the right Heading required: 313˚ + 8˚ = 321˚ Alternatively; Note that question states "The 1:60 rule is used to determine the heading from the fix position to be back on track in approximately the same time it has taken from B to the fix position" and "distance from B: 45 NM"

Calculate the Track Angle Error (TKE) to give us the heading correction so that we can fly parallel to our intended track: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track TKE = (3 × 60) ÷ 45 TKE = 4º (closing angle) By altering heading towards the original track (to the right) by 4°, the aircraft will fly parallel to the original track

To re-join the original track at C, we must find the track correction to reach C: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance to go TKE = (3 × 60) ÷ 45 TKE = 4° => Turning 4º to the right will lead us to fly parallel to the original track

To re-join the original track at C, we must find the track correction to reach C: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance to go TKE = (3 × 60) ÷ 45 TKE = 4° => Turning 4º to the right will lead us to fly parallel to the original track. Turning an extra 4º to the right will direct us to "C". 4º + 4º = 8º to the right to go direct to "C" Therefore, the required heading must be 313ºC + 8º = 321ºC

Given the following:
Runway 31
Surface wind given by ATIS: 265°/32 kt
Variation: 18°E
Using trigonometry, what is the headwind component to the nearest full knot?

key_points: The wind velocity is made of two components, one acting along the runway called the headwind or tailwind component, and the other acting across the runway called the crosswind component
It is possible to calculate the headwind component using the cosine of the relative bearing between the runway and the wind direction
The runway direction is 310º magnetic, and the wind direction given by the ATIS is 265º magnetic
learning.explanation: The wind velocity is made of two components, one acting along the runway called the headwind or tailwind component, and the other acting across the runway called the crosswind component. It is possible to calculate the headwind component using the cosine of the relative bearing between the runway and the wind direction. The runway direction is 310º magnetic, and the wind direction given by the ATIS is 265º magnetic. Head/Tail wind component = Wind Speed x cosine (Relative Bearing) Headwind component = 32 x cosine (310º - 265º) = 23 kts Note: Runway direction is 310º magnetic. The wind direction given by the ATIS is 265º magnetic. Therefore, the variation 18°E is not needed.

content.question: An aircraft's compass reads 002°. The deviation card shows 1°W on northerly headings and the variation is 5°W. What is the aircraft's true heading?

key_points: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T
In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole
The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located
learning.explanation: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T. In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole. The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located. Magnetic Direction, have as reference the Magnetic North Pole and is assigned an angular value of 000º M or 360º M. Variation is the angle between the True and Magnetic North and is assigned in degrees East or West of the True North. If the Magnetic North is west of the True North, westerly variation, the magnetic direction will have a higher angular value than the true direction. If the Magnetic North is east of the True North, easterly variation, the magnetic direction will have a lower angular value than the true direction. Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least The utility of a magnetic compass on the aircraft will depend on the accuracy of its response to the magnetic field of the earth. The metallic structure of the airplane, its engine and equipment can affect the accuracy of the compass, an effect called the compass deviation. Compass deviation is defined by the number of degrees by which unwanted magnetic fields deflect the compass from magnetic north indication (desired indication). Deviation (-) West – Compass Best Deviation (+) East – Compass Least The relationship between the different directions can be expressed by the following table: True Heading (T) Variation (V) Magnetic Heading (M) Deviation (D) Compass Heading (C) 356º 5ºW 001º 1ºW 002º Note: The TVMDC table can be used to relate both Heading directions or track directions.

content.question:
What is the track error angle? Given:
Planned track: 252°(T)
Actual heading: 255°(T)
Actual in-flight drift: 3° right

key_points: Drift is the angle difference from the aircraft’s heading to its actual track (track made good)
Therefore, for an actual heading of 255o, if the aircraft drifts by 3oR, then its actual track will be: 255o + 3o = 258o
The Track Error Angle (TKE) represents the number of degrees by which the Actual Track (or Track Made Good - TMG) deviates to the left or right from the Planned (Intended) Track
learning.explanation: Drift is the angle difference from the aircraft’s heading to its actual track (track made good). Therefore, for an actual heading of 255o, if the aircraft drifts by 3oR, then its actual track will be: 255o + 3o = 258o. The Track Error Angle (TKE) represents the number of degrees by which the Actual Track (or Track Made Good - TMG) deviates to the left or right from the Planned (Intended) Track. When the Actual Track (or Track made good - TMG) is to the left of the Planned Track, the Track Error Angle is considered "Left." Conversely, when the Actual Track (or TMG) is to the right of the Planned Track, the Track Error Angle is considered "Right." Therefore, the TKE will be 252o(T) - 258o(T) = 6º right.

content.question: What is the distance in NM between point A (54°18'N, 008°36'E) and point B (38°41'N, 008°36'E)?

key_points: The two points A and B have the same longitude (008°36'E), so what we are dealing with here is, a Change of Latitude along the same meridian, between 54°18'N and 38°41'N
For Change of Latitude and Change of Longitude calculations, bear in mind the rule: "Same hemispheres - Subtract, Different hemispheres - Add"
The two latitudes are in the same hemisphere, so subtract to find the Change of Latitude: 54°18' - 38°41' = 15o 37'
learning.explanation: The two points A and B have the same longitude (008°36'E), so what we are dealing with here is, a Change of Latitude along the same meridian, between 54°18'N and 38°41'N. For Change of Latitude and Change of Longitude calculations, bear in mind the rule: "Same hemispheres - Subtract, Different hemispheres - Add". The two latitudes are in the same hemisphere, so subtract to find the Change of Latitude: 54°18' - 38°41' = 15o 37'. 1 degree is equal to 60 minutes, so the Change of Latitude can be re-written in minutes as: (15o x 60') + 37' = 937'. Also, it is known that 1' along a meridian equals to 1 NM. Therefore, the distance between A and B points is 937 NM.

content.question: Which combination represents the greatest difference between the air distance and the ground distance for two points?

key_points: In still air conditions and at Sea Level, the air distance between two points is equal to their ground distance
But: Because of the Earth’s ellipsoid shape, with an increase in altitude, the air distance between the two points becomes progressively greater than their ground distance
Thus, the higher the altitude, the greater the air distance in comparison with the ground distance
learning.explanation: In still air conditions and at Sea Level, the air distance between two points is equal to their ground distance. But: Because of the Earth’s ellipsoid shape, with an increase in altitude, the air distance between the two points becomes progressively greater than their ground distance. Thus, the higher the altitude, the greater the air distance in comparison with the ground distance. When a tailwind or headwind is experienced, the air distance will be affected, while the ground distance between the two points will remain the same. The air distance becomes greater when flying in headwind and less when in tailwind. Therefore, the greatest difference between air distance and ground distance is at high altitude with a headwind, which corresponds to the option FL320 with 10 kts headwind.

content.question: An aircraft commences to descent from a Top of Descent at 35 000 ft and 75 NM from the Initial Approach Fix, at which it has to level-off at 7500 feet altitude. What descent gradient is required to achieved the forementioned requirements?

The simplest is to describe how many units of horizontal distance are required for every unit of height gained or lost
This can also be expressed as a ratio, a fraction or a decimal (1 in 10, 1:10, 1/10 or 0
learning.explanation: A gradient can be expressed in a number of ways. The simplest is to describe how many units of horizontal distance are required for every unit of height gained or lost. This can also be expressed as a ratio, a fraction or a decimal (1 in 10, 1:10, 1/10 or 0.10), but the most common is in percentage and is given by the formula: % Gradient = Change of height x 100 / Horizontal distance. For this question, the Change of height is: 35 000 ft - 7 500 ft = 27 500 ft. Thus, the required Descent Gradient is: % Gradient = 27 500 ft x 100 / (75 NM x 6080 ft) = 6.03 %, which is very close to 6.1 %.

content.question: The pilot of an aircraft during descent with constant CAS of 120 kt, observes a TAS of 135 kt at FL080. What will be the TAS, if he/she checks again the instruments minutes later?

key_points: The dynamic pressure is the basic measure of airspeed in the aircraft
The Airspeed Indicators are calibrated to read corrrectly at Sea Level ISA conditions
At a height the air density reduces and therefore the same dynamic pressure reflects a higher TAS
learning.explanation: The dynamic pressure is the basic measure of airspeed in the aircraft. The Airspeed Indicators are calibrated to read corrrectly at Sea Level ISA conditions. At a height the air density reduces and therefore the same dynamic pressure reflects a higher TAS. The same thing would happen, if the air was warmer than standard. Conversely, at a lower height or in colder air than standard, the same dynamic presssure reflects a lower TAS. This means that at height we have two airspeeds, the CAS based on dynamic pressure and the higher TAS than CAS through the air. As an aircraft descends from one altitude to one other lower with constant CAS, but higher to Sea Level, the TAS will be in both cases higher than the CAS, but the difference between them increases as altitude increases and decreases as altitude decreases, until they become equal at Sea Level in ISA conditions. For this question, the TAS will be always higher than CAS during the descent (thus, 119 kt is excluded), but a few minutes later, after FL080, the TAS will be lower than 135 kt, 131 kt.

content.question: An aircraft navigates from A to B on a planned track of 278° over a distance of 75 NM. At a distance of 45 NM, the pilot notices a cross track error of 4° to the right . In order to arrive in B, the pilot should follow a track of…

We have travelled 45 miles so have 30 miles left to run to B

Track Error Angle = (Cross Track Error / Distance Travelled) x 60 When rearranged, Cross Track Error = (Track Error Angle x Distance Travelled) / 60 Cross Track Error = (4º x 45) / 60 = 3 NM off course This now allows us to calculate our closing angle, so we can track directly to B
learning.explanation: The Track Error Angle (TEA) is given as 4⁰ to the right, which allows us to calculate the actual Cross Track Error (XTE) in NM using the 1 in 60 rule. We have travelled 45 miles so have 30 miles left to run to B. content.question: You depart point A at 12:15 and begin a planned route of 80 NM. Your initial heading is 235º. At 12:27 you pass a rail track crossing your path at 90º after travelling 40 NM. At 12:33 the pilot realizes he/she is 4 NM to the left of the intended track. What heading should you fly to reach your intended destination and what will be your ETA?

key_points: With the information provided by the question text, we can calculate the aircraft’s ground speed
The aircraft departs at 12:15 and we know that at 12:27 (after 12 minutes), the aircraft has covered 40 NM

Ground speed = (40 ÷ 12) x 60 = 200 kt At 12:33, the aircraft would have covered a further 20 NM: 12:33 – 12:27 = 6 min (200 kt x 6 min) / 60 = 20 NM At 40 NM + 20 NM = 60 NM along the route (12:33), the aircraft is 4 NM to the left of the intended track
learning.explanation: With the information provided by the question text, we can calculate the aircraft’s ground speed. The aircraft departs at 12:15 and we know that at 12:27 (after 12 minutes), the aircraft has covered 40 NM. Ground speed = (40 ÷ 12) x 60 = 200 kt At 12:33, the aircraft would have covered a further 20 NM: 12:33 – 12:27 = 6 min (200 kt x 6 min) / 60 = 20 NM At 40 NM + 20 NM = 60 NM along the route (12:33), the aircraft is 4 NM to the left of the intended track. Calculate the TKE (Track Angle Error) to give us the heading correction in order to parallel our intended track: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track TKE = (4 × 60) ÷ 60 TKE = 4° If we alter our heading by 4° (towards the original track) we will parallel our original track. In order to re-join the original track, we must calculate the track correction for the distance to go: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance to go TKE = (4 × 60) ÷ 20 TKE = 12º So turning 4° will parallel our track, and turning an extra 12° on top of that will direct us to the final destination. Therefore, 4° + 12° = 16º would be the total alteration required (to re-join the original track). The deviation was to the left, therefore we must fly 16º to the right. Track = 235º + 16º = 251º The aircraft 80 NM – 60 NM = 20 NM away from the destination. At 200 kt, it will cover 20 NM in 6 minutes. The destination will be reached at 12:33 + 6 min = 12:39

content.question: Plotting positions in charts by Dead Reckoning (DR) may be required..

options.A: in areas with high densities of airways and navigation aids.
options.B: during a flight over sea using INS/IRS and GPS navigation.
options.C: during a flight with limited equipment and few navigational aids.
options.D: when any of the radio-navigation, INS or GPS sources are unavailable.

key_points: Navigation by Dead Reckoning is part of the basic training for pilots
Based in the calculation of the position of airplane based in the direction and the ground distance traveled from a determined point
With the introduction of modern navigational techniques such as GPS and conventional radio navigational aids, this may seem outdated technique
learning.explanation: Navigation by Dead Reckoning is part of the basic training for pilots. Based in the calculation of the position of airplane based in the direction and the ground distance traveled from a determined point. With the introduction of modern navigational techniques such as GPS and conventional radio navigational aids, this may seem outdated technique. Reasons for why we continue to teach Dead Reckoning: 1. Creation of a Dead Reckoning encourages the pilot to consider the safest and most economical flightpath, potential threats and eventual consequences of navigational errors. 2. It is an acceptable and approved mean of navigation. Dead Reckoning can be used to navigate under Visual Flight Rules without having to rely on a radio or other navigational aids. 3. It is fail-safe mean of navigation. DR does not rely on any navigational aid, it is therefore a valuable contingency navigation method, even if the the plan is to fly with. Reference to a GPS or other navigation aid.

An aircraft is executing a VFR navigation. The navigation log refers to a leg that begins over CWD VOR/DME. The aircraft reaches CWD VOR/DME at 10:06 UTC and then follows the calculated heading and speed. At 10:21 UTC the aircraft is on radial 247° at a DME distance of 24 NM from CWD VOR/DME. key_points: The aircraft is on radial 247° magnetic
In order to find cross track error, we need to compare the planned Magnetic Track with the actual Magnetic Track

Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least True track (T) Variation (V) Magnetic track (M) Deviation (D) Compass track (C) 241° 2°W 243° - - Calculate Track Error (TKE) TKE = Actual Track – Planned Track = 247° - 243° = 4° Calculate cross-track error The 1:60 rule states that: "For each degree of drift angle you will be one NM off-track having travelled 60 NM along track"

If you are only 20 NM along track, every one degree of drift angle relates to one third of a NM. key_points: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T

The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located
learning.explanation: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T. In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole. The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located. Magnetic Direction, have as reference the Magnetic North Pole and is assigned an angular value of 000º M or 360º M. Variation is the angle between the True and Magnetic North and is assigned in degrees East or West of the True North. If the Magnetic North is west of the True North, westerly variation, the magnetic direction will have a higher angular value than the true direction. If the Magnetic North is east of the True North, easterly variation, the magnetic direction will have a lower angular value than the true direction. Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least The utility of a magnetic compass on the aircraft will depend on the accuracy of its response to the magnetic field of the earth. The metallic structure of the airplane, its engine and equipment can affect the accuracy of the compass, an effect called the compass deviation. Compass deviation is defined by the number of degrees by which unwanted magnetic fields deflect the compass from magnetic north indication (desired indication). Deviation (-) West – Compass Best Deviation (+) East – Compass Least Drift or drift angle, is the angular difference between the track of the aircraft across and it's heading. Always remember that the drift angle is always measured with reference to the heading. The heading is the direction in witch the the aircraft’s nose is pointing for. content.question: Where is it more likely to find high values of variation?

It varies across the Earth between 180º, on a line joining the true and magnetic poles (the magnetic compass is pointing at the Magnetic North Pole, whilst the tail of the needle is pointing at the Geographic North Pole) and 0º, where this line is extended beyond the poles

learning.explanation: Magnetic variation is the angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian. It varies across the Earth between 180º, on a line joining the true and magnetic poles (the magnetic compass is pointing at the Magnetic North Pole, whilst the tail of the needle is pointing at the Geographic North Pole) and 0º, where this line is extended beyond the poles. Lines joining points of equal variation on the Earth's surface are called "isogonals" and the line along which variation is zero is called "agonic line". The isogonals converge at the magnetic poles and at the true poles. The Earth's magnetic pole is slowly moving around the true pole at high latitudes, so variation changes over time.

learning.explanation: Drift or drift angle, is the angular difference between the track of the aircraft and its heading. Keep in mind, to determine the drift the reference is heading to track. Set True Heading (020ºM) under "True Index" 2. Place centre dot over TAS (260 kts) 3. Mark the point where drift (10ºL) and GS (228 kt) meet. 4. Rotate the wind computer until mark is below TAS. 5. Count down from TAS to obtain wind speed (260 - 206 = 54 kt) W/V = 068º M / 54 kt => The question asks for W/V in (ºT), therefore we must apply the variation: Magnetic versus True Use this mnemonic to remember that with variation west, the magnetic direction is going to be "best" or greater than true. content.question: Aircraft departs from A, to point B which is 45 NM away. After 7 min or 12 NM, the aircraft is 3 NM left off track. What is the change of heading required to fly direct to point B.

key_points: Calculate the TKE (Track Angle Error) to give us the heading correction in order to parallel our intended track: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track TKE = (3 × 60) ÷ 12 TKE = 15° If we alter our heading by 15° (towards the original track) we will parallel our original track
In order to re-join the original track, we must calculate the track correction for the distance to go: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance to go TKE = (3 × 60) ÷ 33 TKE = 5º (approx
) So turning 15° will parallel our track, and turning an extra 5° on top of that will direct us to the final destination
learning.explanation: Calculate the TKE (Track Angle Error) to give us the heading correction in order to parallel our intended track: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track TKE = (3 × 60) ÷ 12 TKE = 15° If we alter our heading by 15° (towards the original track) we will parallel our original track. In order to re-join the original track, we must calculate the track correction for the distance to go: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance to go TKE = (3 × 60) ÷ 33 TKE = 5º (approx.) So turning 15° will parallel our track, and turning an extra 5° on top of that will direct us to the final destination. Therefore, 15° + 5° = 20º would be the total alteration required (to re-join the original track). The deviation was to the left, therefore we must fly 20º to the right. content.question: You are planning to fly from waypoint A (46°35'00''N, 175°26'39''E) to waypoint B (28°24'00''S, 175°26'39''E). What is the distance between these two waypoints?

key_points: The two points A and B have the same longitude (175°26'39''E), so what we are dealing with here is, a Change of Latitude along the same meridian, between 46°35'00''N and 28°24'00''S
For Change of Latitude and Change of Longitude calculations, bear in mind the rule: "Same hemispheres - Subtract, Different hemispheres - Add"
The two latitudes are in different hemispheres, so add to find the Change of Latitude: 46o35'00'' + 28°24'00'' = 74o59'00''
learning.explanation: The two points A and B have the same longitude (175°26'39''E), so what we are dealing with here is, a Change of Latitude along the same meridian, between 46°35'00''N and 28°24'00''S. For Change of Latitude and Change of Longitude calculations, bear in mind the rule: "Same hemispheres - Subtract, Different hemispheres - Add". The two latitudes are in different hemispheres, so add to find the Change of Latitude: 46o35'00'' + 28°24'00'' = 74o59'00''. 1 degree is 60 minutes, so the Change of Latitude can be re-written in minutes as: (74o x 60') + 59' = 4499'. Also, it is known that 1' along a meridian equals to 1 NM. Therefore, the distance between A and B points is 4499 NM.

content.question:
Given:
Distance A to B = 150 NM.After 30 NM aircraft is 4 NM to the right of course.What heading alteration should be made in order to arrive at point "B"?

key_points: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning
If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track
The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good
learning.explanation: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning. If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track. The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good. The difference between them is called track error (TE). The angle at which we want to close to come back to the planned track is the closing angle (CA). The CA will depend how much further we want to rejoin the planned track. The 1 in 60 rule can be used to calculate the TE and the CA. TE = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 TE = (4/30) x 60 = 8º The same 1 in 60 rule can be applied to calculate the CA. CA = (distance off-track/distance at which we want to rejoin track) x 60 CA = (4 / (150 - 30)) x 60 = 2º With both TE and CA, we can determine by how much heading change we should apply to regain track: Heading change = TE + CA = 8º + 2º = 10º L The aircraft is right off-track, the aircraft must fly left to regain track.

content.question: The angle between Magnetic North and Compass North is called..

key_points: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T
In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole
The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located
learning.explanation: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T. In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole. The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located. Magnetic Direction, have as reference the Magnetic North Pole and is assigned an angular value of 000º M or 360º M. Variation is the angle between the True and Magnetic North and is assigned in degrees East or West of the True North. If the Magnetic North is west of the True North, westerly variation, the magnetic direction will have a higher angular value than the true direction. If the Magnetic North is east of the True North, easterly variation, the magnetic direction will have a lower angular value than the true direction. Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least The utility of a magnetic compass on the aircraft will depend on the accuracy of its response to the magnetic field of the earth. The metallic structure of the airplane, its engine and equipment can affect the accuracy of the compass, an effect called the compass deviation. Compass deviation is defined by the number of degrees by which unwanted magnetic fields deflect the compass from magnetic north indication (desired indication). Deviation (-) West – Compass Best Deviation (+) East – Compass Least

• Adjusting the True Heading (TH) of 123º for 2°W variation results in 125° Magnetic Heading (MH), not 121º
117°; 4°L; 121°; 1°E; 122°; -3°; 119° • True Track 117° with 4°L drift results in a True Heading of 121° (117º + 4º)
learning.explanation: For this question the following applies: Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least Deviation (-) West – Compass Best Deviation (+) East – Compass Least True track (TT); Drift, True Heading (TH), variation, Magnetic Heading (MH), deviation, Compass Heading (CH) 125°; 2°R; 123°; 2°W; 121°; -4°; 117° • True Track 125° with 2°R drift results in a True Heading (TH) of 123° (125º - 2º). • Adjusting the True Heading (TH) of 123º for 2°W variation results in 125° Magnetic Heading (MH), not 121º. 117°; 4°L; 121°; 1°E; 122°; -3°; 119° • True Track 117° with 4°L drift results in a True Heading of 121° (117º + 4º). • Adjusting the True Heading (TH) of 121º for 1°E variation results in a Magnetic Heading (MH) of 120º, not 119º. 115°; 5°R; 120°; 3°W; 123°; +2°; 121° • True Track 115º with 5°R drift results in a True Heading of 110° (115º - 5º), not 120º. 119°; 3°L; 122°; 2°E; 120°; +4°; 116° • True track of 119° with 3°L drift results in a True Heading of 122° (119º + 3º). • Adjusting the True Heading (TH) of 122º for 2°E variation results in a Magnetic Heading (MH) of 120º. • With +4° deviation (4°E), the Compass Heading (CH) is correctly determined as 116°. When transforming True Heading (TH) into Magnetic Heading (MH) and vice versa, we consider magnetic variation. Variation represents the angle between True North and Magnetic North, expressed in degrees East or West of True North. To convert Magnetic Heading to Compass Heading (CH), we consider deviation. Remember the mnemonic "West is Best, East is Least". Westerly variation increases TH (+), whereas easterly variation reduces it (-). Furthermore, negative values for variation or deviation signify westerly, whereas positive values signify easterly. content.question:
An aircraft which flies a flight leg from A to B point, after 17 minutes is deviated to the right off the planned track by 3 NM. Given the following information, and using the 1 in 60 rule, what is the average drift angle ?
Distance from A to B: 83 NM
Average GS: 108 kt

key_points: The aircraft flying with a GS of 108 kt, experiences a right off-track deviation of 3 NM after: Distance = GS x Time = 108 kt x 17/60 hr = 30
6 NM
The 1:60 rule states that: "For each degree of drift angle you will be one NM off-track having travelled 60 NM along track"
learning.explanation: The aircraft flying with a GS of 108 kt, experiences a right off-track deviation of 3 NM after: Distance = GS x Time = 108 kt x 17/60 hr = 30.6 NM. The 1:60 rule states that: "For each degree of drift angle you will be one NM off-track having travelled 60 NM along track". If you are only 20 NM along track, every one degree of drift angle relates to one third of a NM. If so, 2 NM off-track must equate to a 6º drift angle and 3 NM off-track must equate to a 9º drift angle. Applying the 1:60 rule, an aircraft which is off-track 3 NM after 60 NM, will have a drift angle of 3º. Thus, after 30.6 NM, the aircraft will have a drift angle of: 3º x 60/30.6 = 6º (rounded).

The pilot expects the aircraft to be tracking the 320º radial, but finds out that the aircraft has actually tracked 323º from the VOR. content.question: The charted values of magnetic variation on Earth normally change annually due to...

options.A: an increasing field strength causing numerical values at all locations to increase.
options.B: magnetic pole movement causing numerical values at all locations to increase or decrease.
options.C: a reducing field strength causing numerical values at all locations to decrease.
options.D: magnetic pole movement causing numerical values at all locations to increase.

key_points: The magnetic variation is caused by the different locations of the geographic (true) North Pole and the magnetic North Pole
The horizontal component of the Earth’s magnetic field is the part that is detected by the compass needle in order to determine Magnetic North
Therefore, it is accurate enough to say that variation is the angle between the horizontal component of the magnetic field and the true north direction
learning.explanation: The magnetic variation is caused by the different locations of the geographic (true) North Pole and the magnetic North Pole. The horizontal component of the Earth’s magnetic field is the part that is detected by the compass needle in order to determine Magnetic North. Therefore, it is accurate enough to say that variation is the angle between the horizontal component of the magnetic field and the true north direction. At a specific location, the value of magnetic variation varies slowly over time. In fact, the magnetic pole is constantly moving, causing the values at all locations to increase or decrease. This periodic change is also reflected in the slow movement of the magnetic poles monitored through the various ground and satellite-based stations/instruments. The IRS of the aircraft also contains a variation program. It is supplied to the IRS true North to obtain a magnetic heading, which is ultimately fed to the FMS. The IRS is also normally recalibrated from time to time so that it can maintain the variation accurately enough. Lately, the magnetic pole location is changing more rapidly, approximately at a rate of 30 to 40 miles per year, moving towards Siberia. The need to continuously monitor and update the magnetic variation charts is, therefore, more crucial than ever. LO 061.01.03.01.05: Explain changes of variation with time and position.

An aircraft is following the flight log, and during the flight the wind has been as forecast. Between the M20 junction and the DET VOR, the pilot diverts from the route to avoid low clouds. Once past the cloud the pilot is able to make a visual fix, finding that the aircraft is 15 NM along the route from the M20 Junction but approximately 2,5 NM to the left of that route. By the 1:60 rule, the magnetic heading to fly to arrive at the DET VOR is...

key_points: The 1:60 rule states that: "For each degree of track error you will be one NM off-track having travelled 60 NM along track"
So, if you have travelled for 30 NM the error will be half NM per degree of track error or, if you have travelled for 20 NM, one third NM per degree of track error
If the track error is larger, the error will be proportionally larger, so 60 NM along track a 2o track error will place you 2 NM off track, or 1 NM off track after 30 NM
learning.explanation: The 1:60 rule states that: "For each degree of track error you will be one NM off-track having travelled 60 NM along track". So, if you have travelled for 30 NM the error will be half NM per degree of track error or, if you have travelled for 20 NM, one third NM per degree of track error. If the track error is larger, the error will be proportionally larger, so 60 NM along track a 2o track error will place you 2 NM off track, or 1 NM off track after 30 NM. The rule can be used to determine the track error angle,when the displacement is known, the displacement, when the track is known and correction to intercept, when displacement is known. The correction that must be made to intercept the DET VOR is given by the following formula, which is based on the 1:60 rule: (Distance off track / Miles to go) = (Degrees to intrercept / 60). Solving for Degrees to intercept we get: Degrees to intercept = (Distance off track x 60) / Miles to go = (2.5 NM x 60) / (27 NM - 15 NM) = 12.5o. Thus, since the aircraft is off-track to the left, the correction that must be made to arrive at DET VOR must be to the right, and its magnetic heading must be: Planned Magnetic Heading from M20 junction to DET VOR + Degrees to intercept = 283o (M) + 12.5o = 295.5o, which is very close to 296o.

content.question: What is the only true great circle on the surface of the WGS-84 ellipsoid?

options.A: The great circle that crosses the Equator at 045º (T).
options.B: The track along any meridian from pole to pole.
options.C: The great circle that is coincident with the Equator.

key_points: The planet of the Earth is roughly spherical
Because of its spin, it is slightly fatter at the Equator and slightly flattened at the poles, a shape known as an oblate spheroid or an ellipsoid
On the WGS-84 reference system, the Earth's shape is very close to this kind of ellipsoid
learning.explanation: The planet of the Earth is roughly spherical. Because of its spin, it is slightly fatter at the Equator and slightly flattened at the poles, a shape known as an oblate spheroid or an ellipsoid. On the WGS-84 reference system, the Earth's shape is very close to this kind of ellipsoid. The Prime Meridian and its anti-meridian form an ellipse which is not a great circle. Thus, the only true great circle on the surface of the WGS-84 ellipsoid is the great circle that is coincident with the Equator.

content.question: An aeroplane is climbing with a constant TAS of 220 kt and a headwind of 40 kt. If the rate of climb is 1300 ft per min, what climb gradient is achieved?

Thus, for a RoC of 1 300 ft/min and a Groundspeed of: TAS - headwind component = 220 kt - 40 kt = 180 kt, the Climb Gradient will be: Climb Gradient(%) = (1 300 fpm / 180 kt) x (6000 / 6080) = 7

Any information (ATIS, ATC) given to help pilot to line up the aircraft with runway for take-off or landing is magnetic, because runways directions are always magnetic

It is possible to calculate the crosswind component taking the sine and the cosine of the relative bearing between the runway and the wind direction. Note that question asks for the alteration to fly parallel to the intended track => 12º would only be correct if the question asked us to re-join our original track

In such case, we would have to find the track correction for the distance to go: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance to go TKE = (8 × 60) ÷ 80 TKE = 6º So turning 6° will parallel our track, and turning an extra 6° on top of that will direct us to the final destination

content.question: The value for variation changes with…

key_points: The poles of the Earth's magnetic field are close to the geographic poles, which lie on the axis of the Earth's rotation, but not coincident, so that a compass pointing to magnetic north will not point exactly at the geographic north pole
The angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian, or the difference between the true north and the magnetic north, is called variation and varies between 180o and zero

Because the Earth's magnetic pole is slowly moving around, the variation changes over time and therefore the date of any map showing variation is important, because if it is an old map, its variations will be incorrect
learning.explanation: The poles of the Earth's magnetic field are close to the geographic poles, which lie on the axis of the Earth's rotation, but not coincident, so that a compass pointing to magnetic north will not point exactly at the geographic north pole. The angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian, or the difference between the true north and the magnetic north, is called variation and varies between 180o and zero. Because the Earth's magnetic pole is slowly moving around, the variation changes over time and therefore the date of any map showing variation is important, because if it is an old map, its variations will be incorrect. Thus, the pilots should always fly with the most up-to-date chart for flight safety reasons. If the chart is republished at frequent intervals, the variation should be comparatively recent as well.

learning.explanation: When a magnetic needle is influenced only by the Earth’s magnetic field, it points to magnetic north. But, if the compass is installed in an aircraft, the Earth's magnetic field will be distorted by the metal and the electrical equipment around it and the needle now deviates slightly from magnetic north, indicating a direction of 000°, known as compass north. Deviation varies with magnetic latitude, aircraft heading and changes in aircraft electronic equipment. The difference between the direction of magnetic north and that of compass north is called "deviation". Deviation is measured in degrees and is described as "East" (+) or "West" (-). And since the compass heading is 1° less than the magnetic heading, then the deviation is 1°E.

content.question: Seasons are due to the…

options.A: Earth’s rotation on its polar axis.
options.B: inclination of the polar axis with the ecliptic plane.
options.C: variable distance between the Earth and the Sun.
options.D: Earth’s elliptical orbit around the Sun.

key_points: All planetary orbits, including the Earth's, are elliptical with the Sun at one focus
The Earth moves slightly closer and further away from the Sun during its yearly orbit
The point where the Sun is furthest from the Earth is Aphelion and where it is closest, Perihelion
learning.explanation: All planetary orbits, including the Earth's, are elliptical with the Sun at one focus. The Earth moves slightly closer and further away from the Sun during its yearly orbit. The point where the Sun is furthest from the Earth is Aphelion and where it is closest, Perihelion. The highest speed of the Earth in its orbit is at perihelion, the lowest at aphelion. Perihelion occurs in early January and Aphelion in early July. These differences in range are not enough to cause the seasons, but these come from the Earth's tilt or, using astronomic terminology, the inclination of the Earth's axis of rotation to the ecliptic (where ecliptic, the name given to the apparent path of the Sun on the celestial sphere). When the northern hemisphre is tilted most towards the Sun, it experiences northern hemisphere summer. When it tilts most away, it is northern hemisphere winter, but southern hemisphere summer.

learning.explanation: A freely suspended magnet will align itself with the Earth's magnetic field. The total field (T) is resolved into a horizontal component (H) and a vertical component (Z). The compass’ needle will align itself with the Earth's horizontal component (H) of the Earth's magnetic field. The compass is ineffective near the poles. learning.explanation: All planetary orbits, including the Earth's, are elliptical with the Sun at one focus. The Earth moves slightly closer and further away from the Sun during its yearly orbit. The point where the Sun is furthest from the Earth is Aphelion and where it is closest, Perihelion. The highest speed of the Earth in its orbit is at perihelion, the lowest at aphelion. Perihelion occurs in early January and Aphelion in early July. This must not be mistaken for the cause of the seasons, as actually the Earth is farthest from the Sun in early July, and therefore receives slightly less energy per day, and yet the Northern Hemisphere is in the height of Summer. The seasons are instead set by the inclination (tilt) of the Earth.

content.question:
An aircraft is passing point A at 12:05 with a GS of 140 kt. ETA at point B is 13:20. At 12:35, a deviation of 7 NM left of the intended track is noticed. To fly direct to point B from this point the pilot must change his/her track:
(Note: use 1:60 rule)

key_points: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning
If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track
The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good
learning.explanation: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning. If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track. The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good. The difference between them is called track error (TE). The angle at which we want to close to come back to the planned track is the closing angle (CA). The CA will depend how much further we want to rejoin the planned track. The 1 in 60 rule can be used to calculate the TE and the CA. TE = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 Planned track distance flown = 140 x 30’ = 70 NM TE = (7/70) x 60 = 6º The same 1 in 60 rule can be applied to calculate the CA. CA = (distance off-track/distance at which we want to rejoin track) x 60 Distance at which we want to rejoin track = 140 x 45’ = 105 NM CA = (7/105) x 60 = 4º With both TE and CA, we can determine by how much heading change we should apply to regain track: Heading change = TE + CA = 6º + 4º = 10º R The aircraft is left off-track, the aircraft must fly right to regain track.

content.question: The diameter of the Earth is approximately...

key_points: The diameter of Earth depends on where you are measuring it from
The Earth is not a perfect sphere, and so it has a different diameter around the equator than it does from pole to pole
We know that at the Equator, 1º Longitude = 1NM
learning.explanation: The diameter of Earth depends on where you are measuring it from. The Earth is not a perfect sphere, and so it has a different diameter around the equator than it does from pole to pole. We know that at the Equator, 1º Longitude = 1NM. Based on that, the circumference of the Earth may be calculated as follows: Earth circumference at the Equator = 360º x 60 NM = 21 600 NM => 21 600 NM x 1.852 = 40 000 km Circumference = π x diameter (π = 3.14) 40 000 km = π x diameter diameter = 40 000 km ÷ π diameter = 12 732 km Alternatively, you can just remember that the Earth's circumference (the distance all the way around the equator) is approximately 40 000 km (21 600 NM) and its diameter (the distance from one side to the other through Earth's center) is roughly 12 700 km.

The pilot of a light twin-engined aircraft has filled in the flight log correctly for a charter flight to Nice in France, with the fuel recorded in litres. What is the new estimated remaining fuel at EBROX?

key_points: The aircraft covered the flight leg from SOPET to TORDU in: 06:46 - 06:34 = 12 min
So, its Actual Groundspeed will be: Leg distance / Leg time = (37 NM / 12 min) x 60 = 185 kt
The aircraft from SOPET to TORDU burnt: 415 lt - 385 lt = 30 lt in 12 min
learning.explanation: The aircraft covered the flight leg from SOPET to TORDU in: 06:46 - 06:34 = 12 min. So, its Actual Groundspeed will be: Leg distance / Leg time = (37 NM / 12 min) x 60 = 185 kt. The aircraft from SOPET to TORDU burnt: 415 lt - 385 lt = 30 lt in 12 min. Thus, its Actual Fuel Flow is: 30 lt / 12 min = 2.5 lt/min. The FL, TAS, Track, Heading and Groundspeed remain unchanged from TORDU to EBROX. So, the Flight time from TORDU via LOTOS to EBROX is: Leg distance / Actual GS = (26 NM + 14 NM) / 185 kt = 0.22 hr or 13 min. And, the fuel required from TORDU via LOTOS to EBROX will be: Actual fuel flow x Flight leg time = 2.5 lt/min x 13 min = 32.5 lt. Therefore, the new estimated remaining fuel at EBROX will be: Remaining fuel at TORDU - Fuel required from TORDU to EBROX = 385 lt - 32.5 lt = 352.5 lt, which is very close to 353 lt.

content.question: The BUN VOR/DME is located at 51°07'N,004°50'E where the variation is 0°. An aircraft is flying a true course of 090°, starting at 53°04'N, 003°37'E with the BUN turned on the VOR. When the VOR shows a radial of 360°, what is the range of the aircraft from the BUN?

key_points: Where Variation is 0o, the true meridians coincide with the magnetic ones
Radials are magnetic bearings emanated from VORs, so a 360o radial has a northerly magnetic direction
090° true course means that the aircraft flies eastwards and almost along the same parallel of latitude
learning.explanation: Where Variation is 0o, the true meridians coincide with the magnetic ones. Radials are magnetic bearings emanated from VORs, so a 360o radial has a northerly magnetic direction. 090° true course means that the aircraft flies eastwards and almost along the same parallel of latitude. Thus, its latitude (53°04'N) remains constant, when it crosses the R360 BUN. Variation is 0o, so R360 coincides with the true meridian 004°50'E, which passes through the BUN VOR. The range between the aircraft crossing R360 BUN and BUN VOR is equal to their the Change of Latitude. So, applying the rule "Same hemispheres, Subtract", the Change of Latitude along the true meridian or R360 is: 53o04’N - 51o07’N = 1o 57’ or 117’. We know, also, that "Along a meridian, 1’ corresponds to 1NM". Therefore, the range of the aircraft from the BUN VOR when crossing R360 is 117NM.

content.question: What is the definition of the Geodetic Longitude?

options.A: The angle in the equatorial plane between the line a that connects the Earth's centre with the prime meridian and the line b that connects the centre with the meridian on which the point lies.
options.B: The distance in the equatorial plane between the line a that connects the Earth's centre with the prime meridian and the line b that connects the centre with the meridian on which the point lies.
options.C: The angle in the equatorial plane between the line a that connects the Earth's centre with the prime meridian and the line b that connects the centre with the anti-meridian of the point.
options.D: The distance in the equatorial plane between the line a that connects the Earth's centre with the prime meridian and the line b that connects the centre with the anti-meridian of the point.

key_points: Latitude and longitude are the grid lines you see on globes
Longitude is the angle in the equatorial plane
There is no natural reference for longitude, but the zero line, called the "prime meridian", is taken, by convention, as the line through Greenwich England
learning.explanation: Latitude and longitude are the grid lines you see on globes. Longitude is the angle in the equatorial plane. There is no natural reference for longitude, but the zero line, called the "prime meridian", is taken, by convention, as the line through Greenwich England. For a spherical Earth, latitude and longitude are angles seen from the center of the Earth and only for the longitude is the exactly the same as for an ellipsoid Earth. Geodetic latitude and longitude is used to define a position on the WGS 84 ellipsoid for aviation charts. Geodetic longitude is defined as "The angular distance between the prime meridian and another meridian passing through a point on the Earth's surface" or "The angle in the equatorial plane between the line a that connects the Earth's centre with the prime meridian and the line b that connects the centre with the meridian on which the point lies". Because the vertex of the angle is the centre of the Earth, the same as for geocentric longitude, the value is the same for both types of longitude.

learning.explanation: There are two possible answers for this question. However, the option "By selecting a suitable echo from the display, obtaining the relative bearing and distance, and converting it into a true bearing to plot on the chart." has been confirmed by feedback to be correct in official exams. The pilot may take a relative bearing from an AWR display and would then use the aircraft heading to turn the relative heading into a magnetic or true bearing to. Thereafter, the reciprocal from the ground feature can be back-plotted as true or magnetic. On the other hand, putting the AWR into "mapping" mode allows the radar to reflect off surface features, which can give quite a good indication of the ground profile nearby. For instance, ground mapping radar can allow pilots to distinguish coastlines quite easily, as well as mountain ranges and sometimes even cities. To establish a fix, the pilots would place the AWR in mapping mode and/or tilt the radar down a lot, then look for echoes on the display that show these features, comparing that with a chart to get an idea of their position. It is certainly a skill, and not one that will be passed through the generations of pilots very well in the modern era, as it is almost useless these days. Note: There are a couple of other options that are close to being correct, whilst none of the others are completely true. content.question: A pilot during the pre-flight planning procedure uses an aeronautical chart to find the magnetic variation. Which statement is correct regarding the magnetic variation at a specific position?

options.C: Magnetic variation always increases by approximately 1° every 5 years.
options.D: Magnetic variation changes occur mainly due to the intense solar storms.

key_points: The poles of the Earth's magnetic field are close to the geographic poles, which lie on the axis of the Earth's rotation, but not coincident, so that a compass pointing to magnetic north will not point exactly at the geographic north pole
The angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian, or the difference between the true north and the magnetic north, is called variation and varies between 180o and zero
Due to the dynamic nature of the earth’s interior, due to the changing position of the magnetic material in the Earth, the magnetic field is constantly changing
learning.explanation: The poles of the Earth's magnetic field are close to the geographic poles, which lie on the axis of the Earth's rotation, but not coincident, so that a compass pointing to magnetic north will not point exactly at the geographic north pole. The angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian, or the difference between the true north and the magnetic north, is called variation and varies between 180o and zero. Due to the dynamic nature of the earth’s interior, due to the changing position of the magnetic material in the Earth, the magnetic field is constantly changing. Since, the Earth's magnetic pole is slowly moving around, the variation changes over time and therefore the date of any map showing variation is important, because if it is an old map, its variations will be incorrect. The pilots should always fly with the most up-to-date chart for flight safety reasons. If the chart is republished at frequent intervals, the variation should be comparatively recent as well.

content.question: Where in the northern hemisphere is it more likely to experience high values of variation?

It varies across the Earth between 180º, on a line joining the true and magnetic poles (the magnetic compass is pointing at the Magnetic North Pole, whilst the tail of the needle is pointing at the Geographic North Pole) and 0º, where this line is extended beyond the poles
Lines joining points of equal variation on the Earth's surface are called "isogonals" and the line along which variation is zero is called "agonic line"
learning.explanation: Magnetic variation is the angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian. It varies across the Earth between 180º, on a line joining the true and magnetic poles (the magnetic compass is pointing at the Magnetic North Pole, whilst the tail of the needle is pointing at the Geographic North Pole) and 0º, where this line is extended beyond the poles. Lines joining points of equal variation on the Earth's surface are called "isogonals" and the line along which variation is zero is called "agonic line". The isogonals converge at the magnetic poles and at the true poles. The Earth's magnetic pole is slowly moving around the true pole at high latitudes, so variation changes over time. In 2021, the Magnetic Pole is projected to have moved beyond the Canadian Arctic to 86.4ºN, 156.7ºE.

content.question: An aircraft is descending from FL280 at a constant Mach number of 0.70 in ISA conditions. At the beginning of the descent, the pilot, after checking the instruments, reads a CAS of 274 kt and a TAS of 416 kt. At some point during the descent, when he/she re-checks the instruments, which value of TAS and CAS would he/she expect to read?

key_points: No calculations are required for this question, because it asks for TAS and CAS “at some point during climb” and not at a specific altitude during descent
A usefool tool in determining the changing relationship between EAS, CAS, TAS and Mach in climbs and descents, below the tropopause, is the ECTM graphs
CAS can be considered to be identical to IAS
learning.explanation: No calculations are required for this question, because it asks for TAS and CAS “at some point during climb” and not at a specific altitude during descent. A usefool tool in determining the changing relationship between EAS, CAS, TAS and Mach in climbs and descents, below the tropopause, is the ECTM graphs. CAS can be considered to be identical to IAS. The ECTM graphs are used to determine what happens to the other three speeds when climbing or descending, whilst holding one speed constant, by drawing initially the parameter that is to be held constant as a vertical line and drawing, later, connecting lines to the remaining letters. The lines are always in the sequence "ECTM", in the standard atmosphere and the speed held constant is drawn vertically. During descent with a constant Mach number, both TAS and CAS increase. Thus, since at the beginning of the descent the instruments' cross-check shows a CAS of 274 kt and a TAS of 416 kt, at a lower altitude during the descent, both TAS and CAS speeds are expected to be higher. Therefore, the only option that gives both TAS and CAS higher than 274 kt and 416 kt correspondingly, is CAS: 324 kt and TAS: 430 kt. Learning Objective 061.01.05.03.01: Deduce the CAS, TAS and M relationship in climb/descent/cruise (flying at constant CAS or M).

content.question: At 04:22 an aircraft at FL370, GS 320kt, is on the direct track to VOR 'X' 185 NM distant. The aircraft is required to cross VOR 'X' at FL80. For a mean rate of descent of 1800 FT/MIN at a mean GS of 232 kt, the latest time at which to commence descent is:

key_points: Required ROD is given in feet per minute (ft/min
Altitude needed to descend (ft), 37 000 - 8 000 = 29 000 ft, with a rate of descend of 1800 ft/m
learning.explanation: Required ROD is given in feet per minute (ft/min.). Altitude needed to descend (ft), 37 000 - 8 000 = 29 000 ft, with a rate of descend of 1800 ft/m. 1800 ft/min = 29 000 ft / Minutes to descend Minutes to descend = 29 000 / 1 800 = 16’ The aircraft will be flying during 16 minutes to descend from FL370 to FL080 at an average G/S 232 kts. Distance flown while descending = 232 x 16’ = 62 NM. While in cruise the aircraft will fly 185 - 62 = 123 NM with a G/S 320 kts. Cruise FT = 123 / 320 = 23’ After flying for 23 minutes the aircraft will reach the TOD. 04º22’ + 0º23´ = 04º45’

At 10:07 you make a note of your position (shown on the image) over the intersection of highways A3 and A92 (N48°49.0', E012°56.3"). Consider the DR positions DR-1 to DR-4 shown on the image. Given the following information, determine your DR position at 10:19.
TAS: 107 kt
Wind: 110°/35 kt
True heading: 130°

key_points: For this question using your Navigation/Flight computer, apply the following steps: Place the centre dot over TAS 107 kt
Rotate the disk until wind direction 110o is under the True index
Mark wind velocity 35 kt below the centre dot
learning.explanation: For this question using your Navigation/Flight computer, apply the following steps: Place the centre dot over TAS 107 kt. Rotate the disk until wind direction 110o is under the True index. Mark wind velocity 35 kt below the centre dot. Rotate the disc until the true heading 130o is under the True index. The mark shows a drift 9o right and Groundspeed 75 kt. Drift is the angle difference from heading to track, so the True Track is: True Track = True heading + Drift = 130o + 9o = 139o. And the distance covered from 10:07 to 10:19 (in 12 minutes) with a Groundspeed of 75 kt is: Distance = 75 kt x 12/60 hr = 15 NM. Therefore, drawing on the chart with your plotter a true track of 139o and measuring a distance of 15 NM, the DR position at 10:19 will be: DR-3 (N48°37.3', E013°10.9').

content.question:
Refer to figure.
After 15 minutes of flying with the planned TAS and TH the aircraft is 2.5 NM South of the intended track and 2.5 NM ahead of the dead reckoning position. To reach destination B from this position, the TH should be:

key_points: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning
If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track
learning.explanation: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning. If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track. 1. The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good. The difference between them is called track error (TE). 2. The angle at which we want to close to come back to the planned track is the closing angle (CA). The CA will depend how much further we want to rejoin the planned track. The 1 in 60 rule can be used to calculate the TE and the CA. TE = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 The same 1 in 60 rule can be applied to calculate the CA. CA = (distance off-track/distance at which we want to rejoin track) x 60 2.5 nm is the off-track distance; know we need to determine the distance flown along the planned track. 15' x 130 = 32.5 nm 2.5 nm ahead of the dead reckoning position: 32.5 + 2.5 = 35 nm TE = (2.5/35) x 60 = 4,3º R Point along track at which we want to rejoin the track: 50 - 35 = 15 nm CA = (2.5/15) x 60 = 10º R With both TE and CA, we can determine by how much heading change we should apply to regain track: Heading change = TE + CA = 4,3º + 10º = 14,3º The aircraft is right of track, the aircraft must fly left: New heading = 95º - 14,3º = 80,7º

content.question:
Using a mechanical computer, determine the TAS of the aircraft. Given the following information:
Altitude: 3 000 ft
QNH: 1 046 hPa
OAT: +10 °C
CAS: 154 kt

key_points: To calculate the TAS from a given CAS with the flight computer, we must calculate the pressure altitude (altitude based on standard pressure setting)

Changing the altimeter setting from a QNH of 1046 hPa to a lower pressure setting (1013 hPa), the reading will decrease: IA = 3000 ft - (1046 - 1013) hPa x 30 ft/hPa IA = 3000 ft - 33 x 30 ft = 3000 ft - 990 ft = 2010 ft Now, using the Flight Computer: Align the pressure altitude window (2 010 ft) with the OAT (+10ºC); Once the wheel is aligned, find the CAS of 154 kts on the inner most scale
You should then be able to read the TAS of 158 kts on the outer scale
learning.explanation: To calculate the TAS from a given CAS with the flight computer, we must calculate the pressure altitude (altitude based on standard pressure setting). Changing the altimeter setting from a QNH of 1046 hPa to a lower pressure setting (1013 hPa), the reading will decrease: IA = 3000 ft - (1046 - 1013) hPa x 30 ft/hPa IA = 3000 ft - 33 x 30 ft = 3000 ft - 990 ft = 2010 ft Now, using the Flight Computer: Align the pressure altitude window (2 010 ft) with the OAT (+10ºC); Once the wheel is aligned, find the CAS of 154 kts on the inner most scale. You should then be able to read the TAS of 158 kts on the outer scale.

Descent: from FL300 to FL50

key_points: At FL180, the ISA temperature is 15 - 2(18) = -21ºC
The OAT is ISA - 10ºC, so OAT = -21 - 10 = -31ºC Using a suitable flight computer (we have used a CRP-5), in the AIR SPEED window, line up 18 000 ft with -31ºC
Then find the CAS of 180 kt on the computer inner scale, and read off the TAS of 233 kt on the outer scale
learning.explanation: At FL180, the ISA temperature is 15 - 2(18) = -21ºC. The OAT is ISA - 10ºC, so OAT = -21 - 10 = -31ºC Using a suitable flight computer (we have used a CRP-5), in the AIR SPEED window, line up 18 000 ft with -31ºC.
